cras—it is his dwelling-house—I reside with him—the prisoner used to come as a charwoman, and was discharged last July—after she left I missed the key of our street door—on the night of the 7th April, about a quarter past nine o'clock, my brother Thomas went out—I saw him leave the house, and am confident he shut the street door after him—I did not see him do so, but I was on the stairs and distinctly heard the door shut—it has a peculiar sound when it shuts—there is no getting in at the window, the area is wide—the windows were all down, and I believe fastened—about a quarter of an hour afterwards I was in the kitchen and distinctly heard a key put in the street door, the door opened, and then shut to—after that I heard a noise in the parlour like a person tumbling over the chain—I came up from the kitchen and went into the passage with a light—I listened for a minute, then went to open the door, and it was put to directly—in half a minute it opened and the prisoner came out with the tea-chest on her arm—I pushed her back into the parlonr, locked the door, and locked her in—I fetched a constable and she was taken—when I went in, the tea-chest was in its usual place on the sideboard—when I returned from the station in about twenty minutes, I examined and found the books and papers and ink-stand thrown on the sofa, and the ink spilled on the sofa, and the table-cover all bundled up in a heap on the table—under the sofa I saw the policeman find this key—it is the key of the street door which we had lost—I know it by its being bro
ken—this tea-chest and sugar-basin are mine, the tongs are my father's.

MATTHEW HUTCHINSON (police-sergeant S 124.) On the 7th of April, about half-past nine at night, I was called to Mr. Cooper's—I found the prisoner in the parlour—she was given ipto my custody—she said nothing—I took her to the station—she was Searched there by a female who gave me this key—this other key I picked up under the soil—it opens the prosecutor's street door—the other will not.

Prisoner's Defence. On Saturday I saw Mr. Cooper, sen., and asked him to lend me two shillings; he said he had not got it in his pocket, but if I would see him at the corner of William-street on Monday sight he would give it me; I went and walked as far as the door; it was ajar; I looked in to the parlour, and the prosecutor ran to the door and shut me in; I never saw the caddy till I was at the office; Mr. Cooper, sen., has often been to my house and given me money as a friend.

GUILTY.*—Aged 35.
Transported for Ten Years.

p.hi: Sixth Jury, before Edward Bullock, Esq.

div1.p:
959.
JOHN SMITH was indicted
for stealing 16lbs. of mutton, value 6s. 8d.; the property of
John Hodges, to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined One Month.

960.
HENRY GROOM was indicted
for unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.
ANN ELLIOTT . I am a widow, and keep a chandler's shop in Well-street, Mile-end, New Town. On the 5th of April the prisoner came to the shop in the

evening for half an ounce of common tobacco, which came to three farthings—he gave me a sixpence—I gave him five pence farthing—he went away—I put the six pence into a basin in which there was only two four-penny pieces beside—I am quite certain of that—my daughter came in about two minutes after, and from what she said I went to the basin—I found in it only the two four-penny pieces and the sixpence—no one had been in the shop—on Sun
day, the 6th of April, the prisoner came again—I was in the shop alone—I remembered him again—he asked for a quartern loaf and some other things, which came to sixpence—he put his hand into his pocket and took out a shil
ling—my daughter had then come into the shop and she took up the shil
ling and said, "You gave my mother a bad sixpence last evening"—he said he did not, and he had not been in the shop, but I have no doubt of him whatever.

SARAH ANN GREEN . I am Mrs. Elliott's daughter. About seven o'clock on Saturday evening, the 5th of April, I was in the parlour—there is a window between that and the shop—I saw the prisoner come in, and took notice enough of him to know him again—about two minutes after he was gone I looked at the sixpence in the basin and found it was bad—I put it apart from other money till next day, when the prisoner came again—I knew him to be the same person—I am confident of him—he bought some things of my mother, which came to sixpence, and put down a shilling—I took it up and found it was bad—I told him so, and I told him he had been there the day before—he said he had not, that he had taken the shilling of a young man for some work, and would fetch him—I told him to go and he left the shop—I went a short distance after him—he turned up Booth-street—I saw a constable and directed him to take him—I gave the constable the bad shilling and sixpence.
MICHAEL MAHAN (police-constable H 79.) I took the prisoner, and found on him two good sixpences and 1s. 3 1/2d. in copper—I received this bad shilling and sixpence from Green.
MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of coin to the Mint. This sixpence and shilling are both counterfeit.
Prisoner's Defence. On Saturday evening I was not near the shop; I was selling books about seven o'clock.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

961.
GEORGE TAYLOR,
JOHN MORRELL , and
JOHN SHEP
HERD were indicted for
stealing 4 trusses of hay, value 12s., the goods of
William Larman, the younger, their master;
RICHARD ANGLE
, for feloniously harbouring the said prisoners; and
WILLIAM BANKS
, for feloniously receiving the said hay, well knowing it to have been stolen.—2nd COUNT, stating it to be the goods of
Richard Dixon.

WILLIAM LARMAN, JUN . I reside at Enfield, and am in the habit of sending hay to Whitechapel-market—Taylor, Morrell, and Shepherd were carmen of mine. On the 20th of March I sent by them several carts to London loaded with hay—they started about two o'clock in the morning—Taylor took a load of clover hay—Morrell had a load of cinqfoil—Shep
herd and James Ovenall had each a load of clover bay—I went up to Whitechapel-market, and got there a little before nine o'clock—I found the carts all there, and apparently all rightly loaded, with thirty-six trusses in

each load—this ticket was given me when I got there—it is a ticket of Mr. Sweeting's, my hay salesman, and indicates that Mr. Dixon, of Bar
bican, had bought three loads of clover and one of cinqfoil—I gave this ticket to Taylor to take there, and it was his duty to bring me back a counter ticket, acknowledging the receipt of the hay at Mr. Dixon's—I then sent off the four loads referred to in this ticket to go to Mr. Dixon's, and they went out of the market together—I think Taylor's cart went first, but I am not quite certain—it was their duty to go directly to Mr. Dixon's—Brick-lane would be their way to go if they went by Spitalfields church—Banks's shop is in Brick-lane, but it is some distance beyond where they ought to have turned to go by Spitalfields church—his shop is out of their way—some information reached me, and I went to Banks's shop, about ten o'clock or a few minutes after—I found one of my carts which had the load of cinqfoil, which Morrell had the charge of, standing at Banks's side door, and Banks was standing by the tide, of it—directly Banks saw me he made away into his shop—I went up to Morrell, and asked him what he wanted with his cart there—he looked down on the ground, and said they had been leaving a truss of hay a-piece.

Q. Did he say they or we have been leaving a truss of hay a-piece, or "I have been putting a truss of clover in at Banks's?" A. He said, "We have been leaving a truss of hay a-piece"—I am sure he said "a-piece"—Banks heard that—he was not two yards off me—I told Morrell I should take him before a Magistrate—he then drove on—Banks went in—I went in, and spoke to him about receiving hay of mine, and he begged for mercy—I did not see any clover or cinqfoil hay in his shop at that time, but I saw some meadow hay which I knew to be mine—I went to the market, and then went back to Banks's with the constable—I did not take a cart with me, but one came afterwards—I looked in a back place at Banks's, and saw three trusses of clover and a truss of cinqfoil, which I know to be mine, and to be part of that which had been sold to Mr. Dixon, and which is referred to in this note—I received the other ticket between eleven and twelve o'clock that day from Charles Taylor.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Just recollect yourself, was not what Morrell said when you asked him what he did there, "I have been putting a truss of clover hay a-piece off each cart at Mr. Banks's?" A. Yes.
COURT. Q. Did he say, "They hare been putting a truss of clover hay each," or "I have," or "We have?" A. "I have been putting a truss of clover bay a-piece."
ROBERTSON SWEETING . I am salesman at Whitecbapel for Mr. Larman—I sold these four loads for him to Mr. Dixon on the 20th of March—I gave this sale note to Mr. Larman.

JAMES OVENALL . I am fourteen years old; I have been in the employ of Mr. Larman since last harvest; I live with my mother, at Enfield Wash. On the 20th of March I went to town with a load of clover of my master's—there were as many as eleven carts of Mr. Larman's went to town that morning together—Taylor drove one of clover, Morrell one of cinqfoil, and Shepherd and I had each one of clover—we got to Whitechapel about six o'clock—after the hay was sold I saw a ticket given to Taylor—we all four left the market together—Taylor went first, and the other three fol
lowed—we went down into Spitalfields—I do not know the name of the street—all four stopped there—two trusses of hay were taken off Taylor's cart, two off Shepherd's, and two off mine—they were all put on Morrell's

cart—Taylor, Shepherd, and Morrell were all present at the time it was done—I do not know what was done with the trusses afterwards—Tay
lor's cart, and Shepherd's, and mine then went on, and unloaded at Mr. Dixon's—Morrell did not start to go there at the time we did, but I saw him coming after us all the way we went to Mr. Dixon's—Banks's shop is in Brick-lane—where we stopped was ever so far from Banks's shop—our carts went a little way up Brick-lane, and then turned off in the direc
tion of Mr. Dixon's—Morrell overtook us almost as soon as we got to Mr. Dixon's—Taylor's cart and Shepherd's went first into Mr. Dixon's yard—I waited outside till they were both unloaded, and then I drove in—the hay was taken in at the loft at Mr. Dixon's—we then went home with our carts—we stopped at the Wagon and Horses, at Hoxton, and had our dinner—we had not stopped at any house before that—when we had got pretty well home that day I received 1s. 6d. from Morrell—he did not say what it was for—I thought it was for the clover, but nothing was said about it—I saw Morrell give Shepherd 1s. 6d. as he was going down Tottenham—Angle is in Mr. Dixon's employ—I saw him about the yard while we were unloading our carts—I saw him taking some straw in—I did not see him that morning, for I was riding.

COURT. Q. Could you see Morrell follow you all the way? A. Yes—he was a goodish bit behind us—when we got to Spitalfields, Taylor took two trusses of bay off his own cart, two off Shepherd's, and two off mine, and put them on Morrell's cart—I did not see any cart stop at Banks's—we were ever so far from Banks's.

RICHARD DIXON . I am the proprietor of the Repository, in Barbican: I am in the babit of purchasing hay of Mr. Larman, at Whitechapel. On the 20th of March I purchased three loads of clover, and one of cinqfoil—they are what are referred to in this note—according to our mode of doing business, this note would be brought by one of the carmen—I have a clerk named Seers, and the prisoner Angle was in my service—it was his duty to stand at the loft door, to count and weigh the hay that came in, and take the account of it to the counting-house with the salesman's ticket, and get another ticket, which he was to give to the carman—it was a ticket like this, (looking at it,) acknowledging the receipt of the quantity—I think it was about one or two o'clock that day, that I heard something was wrong—I had seen Angle that morning after the hay had come, but before it was unloaded.

ALFRED SEERS . I am clerk to Mr. Dixon. This hay came from White
chapel-market on the 20th of March—this sale-ticket was brought to me, but I do not recollect by whom—I gave this other note to Angle, and, according to the course of business, it was his duty to give this ticket, ac
knowledging the receipt of the hay, to one of the carmen who brought it, to take home to his employer.

WILLIAM MEADING . I was in the employ of Mr. Dixon on the 20th of March, as a bricklayer—I assisted in taking in hay from the carts that came that morning—I was up in the loft, and I saw Angle in the yard at the time the carts were unloading—after they were unloaded I went to the Black Horse public-house, which is close by Mr. Dixon's—I saw Angle there, and Sibley and another of the carters—I saw each of them give Angle 2s., and he was drinking with them—I told him there were eight trusses of hay deficient, with the trusses they had taken back in their carts—he said, "Very well, it is all right."

CHARLES TAYLOR . I was in the employ of Mr. Larman. On the 20th of March I was at Whitechapel-market, and Mr. Larman gave me a mes
sage to take to Mr. Dixon's—I went there, and Mr. Basham gave me a ticket like this, but I cannot read—I gave it to my master.

JOHN BASHAM . I am clerk to Mr. Dixon. I remember Charles Tay
lor coming that morning with a message from Mr. Larman—I think it was between ten and eleven o'clock—I gave him this ticket, which I got from Angle, who was in the yard, taking in some straw—the last two carts were just about going out of the yard—I asked Angle what he had done with the ticket he had out of the counting-house—he said, "Here it is"—this refers to the clover-hay and cinqfoil—he took it out of his pocket—the carts which had left the meadow-hay were gone, the other carts were not—Angle did not give any reason why he had not given this ticket to the carman.

WILLIAM LARMAN
re-examined. I got to Banks's that morning about ten o'clock—his house is in Brick-lane, nearly a quarter of a mile beyond the turning that should be taken to go to Mr. Dixon's—I did not see any of the carts but Morrell's—I sent Charles Taylor to Mr. Dixon's for the ticket, because I wanted to know whether my carts had left Mr. Dixon's, and if he met them he was to ask my men for the ticket—it was about eleven o'clock when I sent Charles Taylor—it was after Banks had been taken into custody, and after I had told Morrell that I would take him into custody—when I sent Charles Taylor, Morrell bad been gone from Banks's door about an hour—there was plenty of time for him to have got to Dixon's, and have told anybody there that I had found him at Banks's—I did not see George Taylor, the prisoner, again till he got home at night.

SAMUEL TAYLOR . I am constable of Whitechapel-market. I accom
panied Mr. Larman to Banks's shop thai morning—I had seen these carts come into the market that morning, but I did not see them go out—I went to Banks's, and found three trusses of clover and one of cinqfoil—I took Banks into custody—I took George Taylor, Morrell, and Shepherd the same evening at a beer-shop at Enfield—they were not sober.

WILLIAM LARMAN
re-examined. Morrell's cart was loaded with cinq
foil—he could not have got clover except from the other men—the clover I found in Banks's shop is what I sent by Taylor, Shepherd, and Ovenall—I could swear to it.

Cross-examined. Q. How do you know it? A. By the growing of it, and the tying of it—there was not much of that clover grown, for the first cut was almost all stubble—I cannot tell how many acres it grew upon, or how much there was of it—I had three loads of clover that day in the market, and they were all sold to Mr. Dixon—I had none then left at home—that was the last of the stack of clover-hay—there had been fourteen loads and six trusses in the stack, and that was the last of it.
(Morrell and Banks received good characters.)

MORRELL—
GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Nine Months.

BANKS—
GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Six Months.

TAYLOR, SHEPHERD, and ANGLE—
NOT GUILTY .

962.
FREDERICK ZADOCK HIRSCHFELD,
JACOB JONES , and
JULIUS HENRICH BRUICK , were indicted for
conspiracy and fraud.
MR. CLARKSON offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

963.
RICHARD JOHNSON was indicted
for assaulting
Thomas Hirst, with intent, &c.
NOT GUILTY .

964.
JOHN ELLARD,
EDMUND AMER,
JOHN MOORE , and
ROBERT WALKER , were indicted for
stealing 1 portmanteau, value 5s.; 1 stock, 3s. 6d.; 1 neck-tie, 2s.; 2 neckerchiefs, 1s. 6d.; 4 pairs of shoes, 12s.; 1 pair of slippers, 2s. 6d.; 5 waistcoats, 2l. 15s.; 6 glass-cloths, 3s.; 1 pair of gaiters, 5s.; 1 handkerchief, 2s. 6d.; 1 pair of trowsers, 16s.; 1 coat, 3s.; and 2 scarfs, 10s.; the goods of
Samuel Pope; and that Walker had been before convicted of felony.

SAMUEL POPE . I am a valet. I am now lodging in Upper Spring
street—on the 25th of March I came from Chelmsford, and brought a portmanteau, containing a black stock, a coat, waistcoat, trowsers, and the other articles stated—I left the portmanteau at Mr. Wells's, the Spotted Dog, in the Strand, on Tuesday, the 25th of March—I went therefor it on the Saturday following, and Mr. Wells told me it had been stolen—I went to the station at Bow-street and saw my portmanteau there—this is it—the things that are here are a part of those that were in it—some of them are missing.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What did you leave them there for? A. I left them in charge of the landlady—I was on my way to Shropshire—they were to be left until I called for them—I left them in front of the bar—a person coming in would be able to reach them, but I saw many other things there, and I thought it might be a rule to leave them there—I left them about ten o'clock on Tuesday night, and did not go for them until Saturday morning—there was a name on the portman
teau, but there is not now—I know it, and I have the key of it—I have had it two or three years—here is the mark "Chelmsford" on it—I know the things—here are six glass-cloths, which have my name on them.
MR. BRIKRLY. Q. How far was your portmanteau from the door when you left it? A. Four or five yards, at the farther end of the shop.

WILLIAM WELLS . I am landlord of the Spotted Dog in the Strand. I know the persons of all the prisoners—I only know two of them by seeing them once or twice—the portmanteau was left at my house on the 25th of March'—I saw it safe between one and two o'clock in the morning on the 28th—the prisoners were there along with several more—they had something to drink, and got larking with each other—I looked round and missed several of the persons, and the portmanteau was gone—my house is a booking-office, and I keep it open in consequence of serving the persons from the Weekly Messenger and the Observer office—I have seen Moore once or twice.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNR. Q. Have you a distinct recollection of Amer being there? A. Yes, I have known him ever since I have kept the house—I am sure he was there, and he might have been there early in the evening—we have a great many come in—I do not take a very accurate note of what time they come in or go out—I should have had 2d. for booking if I had kept this portmanteau safe—Amer bore a good cha
racter, to the best of my belief.
Cross-examined by MR. BALDWIN. Q. Do you know Walker? A.

Yes—he was there, to the best of my belief—I had not sufficient know
ledge of him to know who he was then.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. Have you known Ellard long? A. No—I recollect his being there, standing at the back of the engine, talking and laughing with the rest—there were about ten of them—they had half a pint of gin amongst them—there were about five there when I missed the portmanteau, and I asked them what had become of the rest—I was not aware that any of them were tipsy—Ellard might have been tipsy—I will swear he was in my place after twelve o'clock that night—he was there between one and two o'clock—I have seen him there on several occasions, and I have noticed when he came he took a particular stand against the engine.
Moore. Q. Can you swear I was there? A. To the best of my belief—if not, it was a person very much like you—I do not know that I should like to swear positively that you were.
MR. BRIERLY. Q. Which of them will you swear to? A. Amer and Ellard, and to the best of my belief Moore and Walker were there.

GEORGE TURK . I am a cab driver. On Friday morning, the 28th of March, I was the first cab on the rank near St. Clement's church, near the Spotted Dog—I was asleep, and was awoke by my cab door being opened, and two persons got in—two other persons got outside, and I was ordered to drive to Short's-gardens, Drury-lane—I went there, pulled up to a num
ber, and received 1s.—there was a portmanteau taken out of the cab, but I cannot say which of them had it in their hand—I got on my box, and turned round, and the portmanteau was taken into the house—I know Amer was one of the men—he is a driver at well as myself—he was one who was outside the cab, and Moore was the other—I did not look to see who I had got inside, but when I set them down I saw it was Walker and Ellard—when I turned to drive away I saw a policeman, and he asked the number of ray badge—I had a conversation with him, and he went to the house which the prisoners had gone into.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What time was this? A. Between two and three o'clock—I never heard anything against Amer.

Cross-examined by MS. BALDWIN. Q. You say Walker was one who got out of the cab? A. Yes—I had never seen him before—I saw him again at the station—I believe I said then that he was the man—I cannot swear that I did—Walker asked me if he was the man, and I told him I believed him to be one—I told him I was pretty well sure he was the same party—I had no doubt, but I was confused—he is the man that got out of the cab—I had known Ellard before by his using the same watering-house—it was not very dark, there was a gas just by—I did not look very particularly at him—I do not know anything particular about his person.
Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. Did Ellard stagger out of the cab? A. I cannot say that he did—I believe they had been drinking.
Moore. Q. Will you swear I was in your cab that night? A. No—I swear you were outside—I swore so at the station.

GEORGE DOWNS (police-constable F 101.) On the morning of the 28th of march, in conswquence of seeing the cab driven by Truk, I stopped him, and then I went to the second floor back room of a lodging-house—I saw the four prisoners standing round a bed in the room—Hannan, who keeps the house, was in the room—one of the prisoners, and to the best of my belief it was Moore, asked Hannan to advance 4s. on the things, whick

were then strewed about the room—Hannan made some reply that he would not, or had not the money to lend them—I remained on the stairs for some time—Hannan left the room—I then heard a conversation with the pri
soners about what they would do with the things, and they came to the conclusion that they would wack the swag—I then got four other constables, and gave the whole four prisoners into custody—when I got back to the room Walker had just walked into the adjoining room, and was taken there—this is the portmanteau I found in the room, and the property.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How could you see into the room? A. There was a candle in the room, and the door was not shut close—I was gone five or six minutes for the other constables—I had left a man at the door at the bottom—I am quite sure the persons who were in the room when I got back were the same who were there before—I stood peeping at them about five minutes.

Cross-examined by MR. BALDWIN. Q. Will you swear that Walker was there when you went up? A. Yes—I have known him for years—I heard bis voice, saying they would wack it, when they came to the con
clusion that they must wack the swag—they were all in close con
versation before I went to get assistance—it is a low lodging-house, where people pay 2d. or 3d. for a bed—there was nobody in that room but the prisoners and the landlord—there were five other persons in the room that Walker went into, where he was apprehended.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. You had seen the landlord in the room before you went for your brother constables? A. Yes—he came out of the room—I was standing in a recess on the stairs—he brushed against me, and he said, "Who is here?"—I said, "It is I, Hannan"—(be knew me)—Ellard appeared to be sober.
Moore. Q. Will you swear that I asked Hannan to lend 4s. on the property? A. Yes, it was your voice—you were directing your attention to him at the time.

JAMES HANNAN . I live at No. 28, Sbort's-gtrdens, Drury-lane. Moore has lodged with me, off and on, for six months. On the morning of the 28th of March, he asked me for the key—I got out of bed, gave him the candle and the key, and he went up to his room, I suppose—I went up to that room in about four minutes afterwards, and the policeman was behind me—I saw three young men in that room, whom I had never seen before—I did not take proper notice of them, and cannot swear to them—the po
licemen took those four men—I did not see anything that was inside the room—Moore asked me to lend him 4s. till the morning—I said I had not such a thing, which I had not.
Moore. Q. Did I ask you to lend me 4s. on any property? A. No.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. Were you in the room before you saw the prisoners taken? A. No—I went up stairs, and the police
man tapped me on the shoulder, and said, "Don't speak a word," and I did not—I stood still for very near ten minutes.

Moore's Defence. I went home to go to bed; I had not been in half-an
hour when the policeman knocked; I opened the door, and in be walked, and four other policemen, and he pulled a portmanteau from under the bed; he said, "It is all right!"—I said, "I don't know what you mean."

GEORGE FOSTER (City police-constable, No. 425.) I produce a certifi
cate of Walker's former conviction, which I got at Mr. Clark's office—(read Convicted
16th Sept., 1844, and imprisoned six months)—the prisoners is the person.
(Ellard received a good character.)

ELLARD—
GUILTY . Aged 25.

AMER—
GUILTY . Aged 24.

MOORE—
GUILTY . Aged 33.

WALKER—
GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Transported for Seven Years.

965.
JOHN IRVINA was indicted
for stealing 1 ladder, value 5s., the goods of
Henry William Dring, in a vessel, in a port of entry and dis
charge.

CHARLES JAMES ARNOLD . I am ship-keeper of the schooner Bailard, which was lying in the East and West India Docks. On the 22nd of March I lost a three-step ladder, which I had seen safe on the deck at three o'clock that day—I asked the prisoner who was mate of the Provi
dence, which was lying alongside of the schooner, if he had got my ladder—he said, no—on the Thursday following I got an officer, aud went with him on board the Providence—I saw the ladder found on board the Provi
dence aft the pump-well—it belonged to Messrs. Foster and Smith, African merchants, and owners of the schooner—the captain's name if Henry William Dring.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Had you the charge of the schooner? A. Yes—tbe captain was out of the vessel—a vessel called the Sea Witch was lying astern of the Providence—have heard that the persons on board that vessel bad stolen the ladder belonging to the Provi
dence—tbe prisoner said that as they had taken his ladder, he had taken mine—he would derive no advantage from the ladder, it was for the use of the ship.
NOT GUILTY .

966.
THOMAS HALLIDAY was indicted
for stealing 1 watch, value 10s., the goods of
Sarah Overy.

THOMAS CARTER. I am waiter at the Caledonian Hotel, Robert-street, Adelpbi. On the 3rd of April, at eleven o'clock at night, I was in the pantry, and the housekeeper called to me—I went out at the front door, and iaw the prisoner in the act of getting over the railing from inside the area—I took him by the collar and said, "Young man, what do you do here?"—he said, "I have only been down to find a water-closet"—he asked me to let him go—I said, "Certainly not"—he seemed to take something from his pocket, but I could not see what it was, and he put it into a hole in the wall where the gas-pipe runs—I seat for the policeman, and he took the prisoner—I went to the spot where I had teen the pri
soner put something, and found this watch—I knew it, and I said, "Sarah, here is your watch"—there is an iron bar across the window of the room where this watch had been, but the bar has been broken some time.
SARAH OVERY . This is my watch—it bad been in a room in the area.

GUILTY. Aged 27.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Three Months.

967.
WILLIAM BAKER was indicted
for stealing 1 hamper, value 10s.; and 8 dead pigs, 10l. 17s.; the goods of
Ricbard Parker and another.
MR. BALLANTINE offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: Third Jury, before Edward Bullock, Esq.

div1.p:
968.
WILLIAM HENRY WHITE was indicted
for stealing 3 bottles, value 3d.; 1 pint of wine, 2s.; 1 pint of ale, 4d.; 1 quart of stout, 8d.; 3 half-crowns, 13 shillings, and 7 sixpences; the property of
Gustavus Dunning, his master.—Two other COUNTS, stating it to be the property of the Sheriff of Middlesex.—And another, stating it to be the property of
Laing Johnson.

LAING JOHNSON . I was a wine-merchant, carrying on business at Hammersmith. I had an execution put into my house on Wednesday, the 19th of Feb.—the prisoner was put in possession of my premises by the Sheriff's officer that evening—I found him there the next morning—on the evening he was put in possession there was 17s. 6d. in the till—I examined the till on the Sunday, and there was nothing in it—I did not give him authority to remove wine, or ale, or beer.

JAMES JENNINGS . I was in the service of Mr. Dunning. The prisoner was in possession of his premises—on Thursday, the 20th of Feb., I recol
lect seeing a woman there who had come to him—the prisoner asked me for a light, and went down into the cellar—I saw him take a bottle of ale, a bottle of wine, and a battle of stout, and give them to her.
GUSTAVUS DUNNING . I put the prisoner in possession of the premises on the 19th of Feb.—he was to take the money that was received—I did not give him authority to remove anything.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. It would be his duty to render you an account at the end of the time, of money received, and goods he might happen to sell? A. Yes—he would have to sell, and to account to me for the produce—there was 1l. 5s. due to him—if he had entered the ale and wine against his account it would have been allowed in that manner—I believe he has had no opportunity of rendering his account—I have a little book of his, in which these articles are entered—I do not know when the entries were made.
GEORGE LOW (police-constable T 50.) I took the prisoner—I found 1 1/2d. on him.
NOT GUILTY .

969.
JOHN NASH was indicted
for stealing 1 coat, value 3l.; 1 pair of trowsers, value 18s.; 1/4 of a yard of tweed, 4s.; 3/ 8th of a yard of woollen cloth, 4s.; 1 half-sovereign, 1 crown, 2 half-crowns, and 3 shillings; the property of
William McDonough, his master.

WILLIAM MCDONOUGH . I am a tailor, and live in Gloucester-street, Queen-square—I have a shop in Henrietta-street, Covent-garden. The prisoner was in my employ for six or seven weeks previous to the 22nd of March—it was his duty to work as journeyman in my shop, and take orders there—he slept there—on Saturday night, the 22nd of March, I saw him at the shop, at half-past seven o'clock—I went again on Monday morning, the 24th, between nine and ten o'clock, and found it closed—no one had the care of it but the prisoner—I got in by means of a key which opens the back door in the passage—I found the gas was alight in the shop—I missed 16s. from the desk, a coat, a pair of trowsers, two pairs of

shears, and two waistcoat pieces—I had seen them all safe on Saturday night, the 22nd—one of the pairs of shears, and this pair of trowsers, were on the prisoner's person when he was taken—I gave them him to make—he finished them on the 22nd, and was to deliver them to a gentleman that night—he came to my house at nine o'clock on the Saturday night, and I made him a present of a second-hand pair of trowsers of my son's—I did not see him again till he was in custody.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. You say he was to have taken them home to a gentleman that evening? A. Yes—they are completely finished—I saw him in custody between three and four o'clock on the day I went to the shop—these trowsers, which he was to have taken home on the Saturday night, were then on him—they are worth 18s.—I have not found any of the other missing articles—when the prisoner was at my house at nine o'clock that night he bad a pair of new boots, but he had not these trowsers—I expected him to have taken the trowsers home before he came to me—he did not take them home, and the gentleman refused to take them in—the prisoner never offered them to him.

COURT. Q. How do you know that? A. Because I was obliged to make the gentleman another pair instead of them—I do not know that he did not give them to the prisoner—Richard Harvey occasionally worked for me—I owed him 7s.—I gave the prisoner a 5s. piece, and a half-crown to pay to Harvey, about six o'clock that evening.

RICHARD HARVEY . I live in Drory-lane. I am sometimes employed by the prosecutor—previous to the 22nd of March he owed me 7s., the balance for making a coat—I went on that Saturday evening to bis shop for the money, about eight o'clock—I found the shop closed—I have not received any of the money.

HENRY SMITH (police-constable A 28.) I apprehended the prisoner at a beer-shop in Cromer-street, on Monday, the 24th of March, about half-past three o'clock—I told him it was for absconding with a coat and trowsers, and some money—he did not say anything—he was drank—these trowsers were on him.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Six Months.

970.
DEBORAH RAVEN was indicted
for stealing 11 plates, value 1l. 2s.; 6 cups, 10s.; 6 saucers, 10s.; 2 wine-glasses, 1s.; 2 egg-cups, 4d.; 1 ale-glass, 3d.; 2 rings, 13s.; 2 handkerchiefs, 3s.; 1 pair of cuffs, 6d.; 1 shirt, 3d.; 2 napkins, 1s. 6d.; 3 brooches, 3s.; 1 pair of ear-drops, 6d.; 1 purse, 5s.; 1 snap, 5s.; 2 cups, 6d.; and 1 seal, 3d.; the goods of
Thomas Price Jones, her master.

THOMAS PRICE JONES . I live in Tothill-street, Westminster, and am a pawnbroker. In consequence of information, I went to No. 22, New Peter-street, on the 14th of March—I found a box there—the policeman who was with me opened it—I found in it half a dozen cups and saucers, some plates and glasses, and egg-cups—I knew them to be mine—they have been in our family for fifty years—I then went with the officer to No. 3, Great Titchfield-street—I saw the prisoner there—I saw her searched, and a ring and the duplicate of a purse were found on her—the purse belongs to my daughter—the ring is mine—the policeman searched a box there, which the prisoner said was hers, and in it he found these three brooches, these ear-drops, and other articles, which are mine—the prisoner had been in
my service, and left the 5th of March—I do not know when these articles were on my premises—I did not miss them.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Were not some of them found in the box of a person named Mansfield? A. Yes, the cups and saucers, and some other things—I do not know Mansfield, but he was known to some person in my house, as a kind of sweetheart of the prisoner—these articles of jewellery were kept in my wife's drawer—this purse was taken from my little girl's pocket.

WILLIAM MILLERMAN (police-constable B 95.) I went with Mr. Jones to Great Titchfield-street, and found the prisoner—she was stooping down and putting her boot on, she had a duplicate and a gold ring in her hand—I went with the duplicate, and got this purse from a pawnbroker's—Mr. Jones left the prisoner with me, and she begged me not to show him the duplicate and the ring—I found these other articles at Peter-street.
Cross-examined. Q. Where was Mansfield lodging? A. At Peter-street—some of these things were found there.
JOHN HEALEY . I am shopman to Mr. Jones—this ring, which was found at Mansfield's, is Mr. Jones's property.

CECILIA COSGROVE . I live at No. 19, New Peter-street, Westminster. On the 14th of March the prisoner gave me this scarf, this plate, and this little snap—she came to me on the 5th of March, and left a box—she came on the 13th, and slept there—Mansfield used to come to see her—I taw her give him fifteen plates, two egg-cops, two wine-glasses, a ring, and half a dozen cups and saucers—she told him she bought them at a sale—these are them.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe she said something about being a corpse to-morrow? A. Yes—she said, "Take these, in remembrance of me; I bought them at a sale, and the ring I had from my mother's death, and you will hear to-morrow that I shall be a corpse"—she had got a bottle and some laudanum.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 20.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury. —
Confined Four Months.

971.
JAMES GORING was indicted
for embezzlement.

RICHARD BADRINO . I am a cow-keeper, and live in Old Boswell-court—the prisoner was in my service, and had to go round with milk, and to receive money—I enter in a book an account of what he does not receive, and when he received money, either I or my wife took the account of him, and marked it off in the book—I supply Mrs. Duncan with milk—I did not receive any money on her account, from the 17th of March to the 23rd—I have the book here—I have entries of milk to Duncan, on the 22nd and 23rd of March, but I did not receive any money on either of those days.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Is this book your writing? A. My wife made some of the entries—these entries of 22nd and 23rd of March are my writing—my wife marks the book off as well as me—she took the account more frequently than I did, and she is not here.
NOT GUILTY .

972.
THOMAS WILLIAMSON was indicted
for stealing 11lbs., weight of lead, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
William Dent and another, his masters.
HENRY WILLIAM THOMPSON . I am clerk to Mr. William Dent and

another—they are plumbers—the prisoner was in their employ—on the morning of the 4th of April, I stopped the prisoner as he was leaving the warehouse—I called him into the counting-house, and told him I suspected he had got some lead on his person—he put his hand into his pocket, and pulled out 11lbs. of lead—he said he hoped Mr. Dent would forgive him, it was his first offence—this is the lead—it is my masters'.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. What was the prisoner work ing at? A. Cutting lead into small pieces to stow it tway—it comes to us in large pieces—he was going to breakfast when he was charged with this—he said at once he had a piece of lead—he had worked for my master about two years, and up to this time we had every confidence in him—he said he had broken his knife in cutting the lead, and took this lead to repay him.

GUILTY. Aged 23,—Recommended to mercy, —
Confined One Month.

973.
JANE STANNARD was indicted
for embezzling 1s., the monies of
David Simmonds, her master.—2nd COUNT, for stealing 1 saucepan, value 1s., the goods of >David Simmonds, her master.

DAVID SIMMONDS . I live in Sharpe's-buildings, Tower-hill, and am a tin-plate worker—the prisoner was in my service—she had been with me five days on the 17th of March—she was never authorized to reotive money for me.

CHARLOTTE SULLIVAN . I live in Goodman's-yard. On the 17th of March, I went to the prosecutor's shop, the prisoner was the only penon there—I asked the price of a saucepan—she told me 1s. 9d.—I told her I would give her 1s.—she said it would not do—I was going out, she called me back, and said I should have it—I paid her It. for it—I went afterwards for another saucepan, and told the prosecutor what had happened.

DAVID SIMMONDS
re-examined. The prisoner had no authority to tell anything for me—if a customer came she was to ring the bell for my mother to come down—she never paid me the 1s. for this saucepan—all the things in the shop were mine—I could not miss a saucepan.
LYDIA SIMMONDS . I am the prosecutor's mother—the prisoner never paid me any money for goods sold—on the 17th of March my son was out—the prisoner did not tell me she had sold anything.
Prisoner. I never sold the saucepan.
NOT GUILTY .

974.
SARAH LIMB was indicted
for stealing 12 sovereigns, 12 half-sovereigns, 1 crown, 16 half-crowns, 11 shillings, 8 sixpences, And 3 groats, the monies of
James Nunn.
(The prosecutor being deaf and dumb gave his evidence by signs, which were interpreted.)

JAMES NUNN . I lodged and slept in a back room up stairs at the prisoner's house—no one slept in the room but me—on the morning of the 4th of April, I went out at six o'clock—I left a box locked up in my room, in which was 18l. in gold, And 3l. in silver—there were sovereigns, half-sovereigns, a crown, some half-crowns, shillings, and other silver, and some clothes—I know the money was all right the night before, and the box was locked—I locked it every night and morning—I returned home at seven o'clock in the evening—I could see that my box had been broken open, and the things inside had been all upset—I made the prisoner under
stand

by writing on a slate that my box had been broken open, and the money was all gone—she went up stairs with me, and I showed her my box—she had never seen the money in my box in my presence, but her daughter had—I made signs to the prisoner that I would get a policeman—my money had been in a bag—this is the bag it was in.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. How long had you been lodging with the prisoner? A. Two years and a half or three years—she was a well-conducted woman—her furniture was seized that day—I did not owe her any rent—I cannot tell how much there was in my bag when I received it back.

HENRY WOOD (police-constable K 44.) On the evening of the 4th of April the prosecutor came to me at Poplar station—he showed me his shirt, which was torn—there was another person with him—I went to the prisoner's house in Grundy-street—I found the door partly open, and the prisoner was in the passage—she went iuto a back room—I followed her—she took hold of the prosecutor, and said, "Jem, don't give me in charge, I took your money, and will pay you back again"—she put this bag into his hand, containing six half-sovereigns, one crown, and some other silver—I went up stairs, and found the box with the mark of a chisel near the lock.
Cross-examined. Q. What was the amount of the money in the bag? A. 4l. 16s. 10d.—she gave me a little silver at the station.

CHARLES DAY . I am a broker. I went to the prisoner's house to levy for arrears of rent on the 4th of April—the amount was 14l. 1s. 8d.—she said she could not pay me—I said I was sorry to come to see her again, as I had distrained on her fourteen months before—I proceeded to take the inventory—she said she would get the money—she brought 15l. in sove
reigns and half-sovereigns—she got change, and paid me.
NOT GUILTY .

975.
WILLIAM WINTER was indicted
for assaulting
Eliza Orris, with intent, &c.—2nd Count, for a common assault.

GUILTY on the 2nd Count. Aged 20.—
Confined Twelve Months.

976.
CHARLES WAGSTAFF was indicted
for unlawfully breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
James Leech, with intent the goods and chattels therein to steal.
NOT GUILTY .

977.
CHARLES WAGSTAFF was again indicted
for assaulting
Tho
mas Balcher, a police-officer, in the execution of his duty.—2nd COUNT, for a common assault.

THOMAS BALCHER (City police-constable, No. 618.) I was called on on the morning of the 26th of March to take the prisoner—I asked him who and what he was—he said he did not know—I asked him to give some account of himself—he hesitated, and I said if he did not give an account he must go to the station—I took hold of his collar, and he turned and struck me a violent blow on the mouth, and knocked out two of my teeth.

Prisoner. Q. Did you produce the teeth before the Lord Mayor? A. I swallowed one, I could not produce that—I produced one piece of a tooth—I was under the doctor's hands for six days—I drank one glass of ale next day with your master.
JURY. Q. Was the prisoner tipsy? A. Not when I took him.

SUSANNAH POOL . I live at Mr. Leach's. I sent for the policeman, and gave the prisoner in charge—I saw him strike the policeman, and then the policeman struck him with his staff—the prisoner struck first.
(Witnesses for the Defence.)

HARRIET LEACH . I was present on this occasion—when the policeman was sent for the prisoner stood in the passage, and a scuffle ensued—I did not see who struck the first blow, but I saw the prisoner's elbow catch the policeman in the mouth—the policeman struck him four or five times.

CHARLES LEACH . I am ten years old—I was present—the prisoner and the policeman were struggling, and the prisoner's elbow hit the policeman in the mouth, and then the policeman held him down and struck him four or five times with his staff.
JAMES LEACH . I keep the house where the prisoner was taken—I can swear on my oath that the policeman has not lost a tooth now, for two. years ago he called on me, and I saw he wanted two teeth then.
COURT to THOMAS BALCHER. Q. On your oath, do you swear that you lost two teeth in consequence of the blow the prisoner gave you? do, my Lord.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
confined One Month.

978.
JAMES CORNISH and
WILLIAM CANNON were indicted for
feloniously breaking and entering a building, within the curtilage of the dwelling-house of
George Cossar, on the 9th of March, at Walthamstow, and stealing therein, 1 basket, value 2s.; 15 chisels, 15s.; 11 guages, 11s.; 12 screw-drivers, 12s.; 2 gouges, 2s.; 19 brad-awls, 3s.; 4 saws, 2l.; 30 planes, 5l.; 7 plough irons, 9s.; and great variety of other tools, his property.—2nd COUNT, calling it a shop.

CANNON pleaded
GUILTY, and received a good character.—Rrecommended to mercy. Aged 21.—
Confined Two Years.

GEORGE COSSAR . I am a carpenter, and live at Walthamstow. On Sunday, the 9th of March, I saw my tools safe in my workshop, which ii within a few yards of my dwelling-house—the dwelling-house and work
shop are all inclosed by a pale fence—both have doors opening into tne yard—I missed the tools on Monday morning at seven o'clock—the door of the workshop had been forced open, apparently with a chisel—I saw my tools again on the Saturday following at we Police-court.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. I suppose you had not ustd your tools on Sunday? A. No-they were locked up in my chest, but I looked into the chest—I found the chest broken open.

THOMAS WILLIAM ELVIDGE . I am in the service of Worrall and Pown
all, pawnbrokers. I produce a smoothing-plane, twtnty-six chisels, and fifty-five tools in a basket, which were pawned with roe on Monday, tae 10th, I think—I also produce two planes pawned the name of charles Jones—I do not know by whom.
JOHN MINOAY . A chisel was brought to me by the policeman—I know Cannon, and am quite certain he had that chisel at the time he worked for me.

WILLIAM NICHOLL . I was a policeman at this time, and took the prisoners into custody on Wednesday night, the 12th of March, about nine o'clock—each had a bundle—I went up and said to Cannon, "What have you got here?"—he said, "Tools"—I said, "What tools?"—he said, "Tools I use in my work"—he said, "I have been at work at the docks"—I said, "At the docks at this time of night?"—he said, "If you will go to my master, Mr. Mingay, he will tell you it is right"—I took them to the station—I found six planes in Cannon's bundle—I did not search Cornish's bundle—another constable stopped him, but at the station I observed something bulky in Cornish's pockets—I examined them, and found nine planes—he said, "They are not mine, I am only carrying them for Cannon."

AUGUSTUS BRICE (policeman.) I was at the station-house when the bundle was taken from Cannon—I observed he was bulky, and asked what he had got there—he said, "Feel and see"—I felt and found seven planes, seven plough-irons, and a broken chisel on him—he said he had brought them from the other side of Chelmsford—Cornish said he bad nothing to do with it, he was employed by Cannon to carry them.

CHARLES WOOD . I was with Nicholl at the time the prisoners were stopped—Cornish had this bundle in his hand—I asked what he had got there—he said they were tools—I asked him where he got them from—he said he had been to fetch them out of pawn—I asked where—he said he was a coach-builder and was going into Rosemary-lane to work—the bundle contains five planes.

Cross-examined. Q. Who was present when he said this about Rosemary-lane 1 A. Nobody; he said so in Commercial-road—the other two officers were nine or ten yards before me with the other prisoner—I did not hear what Cornish said at the station.

FREDERICK COSSAR . I am the prosecutor's son. Cornish has worked with me some months ago—I have known Cannon work at a wheelwright's shop close by—I have seen them together on the forest close by, several times—Cornish has not worked in our workshop—he worked as a sawyer—he has been in the shop but not with any of the tools—I know these planes found in Cornish's bundle—they have my name on them—I know all the tools in this bundle—these found in Cornish's pocket have my father's name on them—they are all his, and part of the property missing—we never sell our tools—I have examined the rest of the property found on Cannon—they are all my father's.

CORNISH—
GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Two Years.

979. The said
JAMES CORNISH and
WILLIAM HACK were indicted for
stealing 2 sheep, value 4l., the property of
Charles Tebbutt.—2nd COUNT, for killing them with intent to steal the carcases.

CHARLES TEBBUTT . I live at Leytonstone—my house is on the high road from Stratford, to Woodford—at the back of the house is a meadow where I keep my sheep, and behind that is Hainault Forest—my garden wall abuts on a lane and on the high road, and my meadow on the forest—on the 9th of March I had five sheep in the meadow—in consequence of information I went there on the morning of the 12th, and there were only three sheep—I saw a gap in the fence which parts the meadow and field—in attempting to lift the sheep over, the wool had been torn—there

had been a slight frost, and I traced the footmarks of more than one person t short way—the footmarks were close to where the sheep had been lifted over the fence, and a little way along they were not plain enough to make any observation on them—Want and Prior afterwards showed me the car
cases of two sheep.

GEORGE PRIOR . I am a gardener, in Mr. Tebbutt's employ. On the morning of 12th March I was at work in the garden—I went on the fofest with a policeman about twelve o'clock in the day, and saw him find the ear-case of one sheep about half a mile from Mr. Tebbutt's, on the forest—it was buried under the ground—I took part of the ground off it—on Friday, the 15th, I went with Want and brought that sheep home—we afterwards searched and found another place on the forest, and found another beep's carcase there, which we brought home—the entrails had been taken out and the throats cut—there was a great deal of blood—I do not know the marks on the sheep.

EDWARD WANT . On Tuesday night, the 11th of March, I saw Mr. Tebbutt's sheep safe at a quarter before six o'clock—I went into the meadow about half past nine o'clock on Wednesday morning, and missed two—I went on the Friday with Prior to the forest, and brought home the carcases of two sheep—they were the carcases of Mr. Tebbutt's sheep which I missed on the Wednesday—there was a long red mark from the neck nearly down to the tail, by which I know them—there were no letters on them—the skins are here—I took them off—the entrails had been taken oat before they were buried—the meat and skin were buried.

EDWIN DIVER (policeman.) I was stationed at Leytonstone on the night of the 11th of March—I know the lane leading from the forest of Hainault to the high road, by the side of Mr. Tebbutt's house—it is called Davis-lane—I was in that lane about one o'clock in the morning, and saw the prisoner Hack there, close to Mr. Tebbutt's house, about 100 yards from the meadow—he was just moving—he appeared as if moving his feet—I asked why he was loitering about there—he gave me a saucy answer—I do not recollect his words—he after that said, "I am going to Wood
ford,"and proceeded on his way towards Woodford—I passed the place again, and at two o'clock saw him in company with Cornish—I was going towards the forest, and they were coming from it—I had my lantern—I believe they saw me, but they directly crossed the road, and quickly passed me—I turned my light on them as they passed—they walked quicker when they saw me—I walked after them, and then they ran—I am quite certain it was both the prisoners—I ran also, and overtook Cornish—Hack wa" forward—I asked Cornish what he was doing thew, and why he ran away—he did not give me a direct answer—I turned my light all round him, and saw his hands were covered with blood—I laid hold of him directly, and asked how he accounted for the blood on his hands—he gave me no direct answer, but struck me with his hand in the stomach, which took my wind away—I got hold of him—we scuffled together—he got away from me, and ran towards a fence of Mr. Davis's—I ran after him, but he leaped over the fence, which has spikes in it, and in my trying to get over, a spike ran into my hand—he got into the forest, and got away—I went on Wednesday to where the sheep was found—I watched on Wednesday night and Thursday, and nobody came for the sheep—on the Friday night I found Cornish in custody, and recognised him at once—I went with another officer in search of Hack, on the Monday following—I recognized him, and took him into custody—when Cornish was in custody

the front of his trowsers had blood on them, and also behind, and there was blood on his shirt sleeves and wristbands—I asked how he accounted for the blood—he said the front might be from his nose bleeding—I said, "That don't account for the blood behind"—he said he could not account for that, but he believed that was from the stains of ochre—they appeared to me stains of blood—they were down from the joint of the legs—the blood appeared in the same way as T have seen on butchers' dresses.

JOSEPH BENTON . I am a policeman of Leytonstone—I know the pri
soners, and have seen them together more than once—I was on duty on the 10th and 11th of March—I did not see them together on either of those days.

Hack's Defence. I was in doors; the policeman came and looked all round, and went out again; then they took me out; I was about twenty yards from the house; he asked me if I was out that night, I said I could prove I was at home from eight o'clock at night till seven o'clock in the morning, by three men.

JAMES FAULKKNER . I lodge in the same room with Hack—I came home on the night of the 4th of March, between eight and nine o'clock, and he was then in bed—I went to bed and went to sleep—I got up about five o'clock, he was still in bed—I did not sleep in the same bed—a man slept with him who worked for Mr. Whale, the blacksmith, but he has left him a week or a fortnight back—I do not know his name—George Argent slept in the same bed as me—there were only us four sleeping in the room—I got up before Argent, and left him in bed—I left them all three in bed—Argent is a kind of odd man—he works close by—I do not know the name of the gentleman he works for, or his trade—I think his name is Thwaite—he has some business in town, and lives in a private house—he has a garden, and Argent works in his garden, and cleans knives and forks—I have not seen him do so, but he tells me he does—Hack and the blacksmith were in bed when I came borne that night—Argent came to bed after me—he was sitting by the fire taking his supper when I came in—I left him at his supper when I went to bed—I cannot tell exactly what his supper was—it might Jiave been bread and cheese, or bread and meat—I cannot tell—as soon as I go home I go to bed, and do not sit down ten minutes—he was not drinking anything that I know—he generally has a pipe after supper—I cannot say whether he had one that night—I went to sleep before he got to his pipe—I cannot say whether he had anything to drink while he was smoking that night—his pipe generally lies on the table, and did lie there that night—I am quite sure I went to sleep before be came to bed—I think this was on the 4th of March—I can hardly say what day of the week it was—it may be Wednesday or Tuesday—I think it was Wednesday—I am quite sure it was as early as the 4th of March—I made no memorandum of it, only having heard other people talking of it—I was not before the Magistrate—I heard on the Monday when I went home to dinner that Hack was taken that day for sheep stealing—it came to my mind that he was asleep in the same room with me on the 4th of March—I think it was the 4th of March.

MR. ROBINSON. Q. Is this room where you slept on the ground floor? A. Yes—there is a window to the room opening into the yard—I have been attending here five days to speak for the prisoner—I came of my own accord—I heard he was going to be tried, from my sister-in-law—she is no relation to Hack—she lives in the same party like as we live—she had seen Hack that day—she did not tell me to say it was on the 4th of March that I had been with him.

Q. Who told you it was the 4th of March? A. I heard some young men talking about the 4th of March—they were not of our party—when they said it was 4th of March, I began to recollect all about the 4th of March—I did not recollect the day of the week—I recollected that it was the 4th of March when'the sheep were taken—I was not there when they were taken, only I heard them say about it on the Monday—I then recollected Hack was in the room with me—I am sure that was the day.
COURT. Q. What day of the month was Monday? A. I am no scholar, I cannot think of it now.

GEORGE ARGENT . I am a gentleman's senrant, and work in the garden of Mr. Drake, at Ley tonstone. I can take my oath that Hack was in bed on the night of the 4th of March—it was on the Tuesday—I heard of his being taken up on the Monday following—there were two beds in the room where we slept that night—I slept with John Faulkener—I was in bed first—he sat up by the fire taking his supper—I had just gone to bed before he came in—I do not recollect what he had for supper—he was in the other room—the living room is not the bed-room—he was sitting by the fire when I went to bed—Hack was in bed before I went to bed—Charles Baron slept with him—I cannot tell where Baron is—I was awake when Faulkener came to bed—I cannot tell whether he smoked his pipe before he came to bed—he is in the habit of smoking, and so was I after supper—I had my supper before he came in—I had some pickled pork—I left none for him—I did not finish it—we board ourselves.
NOT GUILTY.

980.
ALFRED CALLOW and
GEORGE MOUNTJOY were indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of April, 1 mare, price 2l., the property of
Thomas Dyer.

THOMAS DYER . I am a carpenter, and live at Forest-gate, in Essex. I had a grey mare on the forest on the 5th of April—I saw her last at two o'clock that day—she is a very quiet mare—I went to look for her in the evening, finding she did not come home at her usual time, and at half-past ten I found her at the station—she was dose against Forest-gate, in West Ham parish, on the Wanstead-flats.

EDWIN DIVEB (policeman.) I met the two prisoners about half-past seven o'clock in the evening, against Can Hall-gate, about a mile and a half from Wanstead-flats—it was not part of the forest—Callow was riding the mare—he had on a jacket and collar—Mountjoy was walking at the head of the mare—this is the bridle they had—(producing a boy's red comforter)—the toll-man stopped them, and demanded his fare, which was 1 1/2d.—Mountjoy said, "Wont it do when we come back?"—I said to the toll-man, "I don't think this is right, I will question the boys"—I asked them who the mare belonged to—they said, "To Mr. Davis, an ironmonger, of Stratford"—knowing there was no such person in Stratford, I said, "Does he keep a shop!"—Callow said, "Yes, he keeps an ironmonger's shop, it has been lately opened"—I said, "How long has it been opened?"—at last Mountjoy said, "I will tell no more lies about it, we took the mare off the forest; I took this off my neck, and Callow put it on the horse's neck, and rode it away;" and they meant to take it to their uncle's stables, in Beer, or Vera-yard, I did not properly understand them at the time.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. You were on duty at the toll-gate in uniform? A. Yes.
NOT GUILTY .
(The prisoners were only 12 years of age.)

981.
JOHN RAINBIT was indicted
for stealing 1 basket, value 1s.; 3lbs. weight of butter, 2s. 6d.; and 3lbs. weight of sugar, 1s. 9d.; the goods of
Samuel Rawlinson, from the person of
Charles Rawlinson.

CHARLES RAWLINSON . I am twelve years old—my father's name is Samuel Rawlinson. On the 3rd of Jan. I had been to Romford to get some butter and sugar—I was in Burley-lane about five o'clock in the evening—the prisoner overtook me—he pushed me down, and took the basket from my hand, with the butter and sugar in it, and went away with it—he did not strike me—I had some money, but he did not take that—I saw him again on the Monday afterwards, against the Pigeons, at Strat
ford—he ran away—I saw him on the Wednesday after, at Stratford, and the policeman took him—I knew his person before, but I did not know his name.

WILLIAM RICHARDSON . I am an inspector of police. On the 3rd of Jan., about six o'clock in the evening, Charles Rawlinson came to me at Illford—he described the person to me, and said he should know him again—I sent an officer with him, but the prisoner was not found—on the Wed
nesday afterwards I saw him again in Stratford—I went to the King of Prussia—there were several persons there—he pointed out the prisoner, and I took him.
Prisoner's Defence. I was not at Barking from Nov. till the last day of Jan.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined Three Months.

982.
JOSEPH KEYS was indicted
for embezzling 12s., the monies of
Henry Higham Cox, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Three Months.

983.
WILLIAM SAVILLE and
ROBERT LEWIS were indicted for
stealing 60 yards of calico, value 1l. 5s.; and 1 wooden roller, 1s.; the goods of
Richard Turner Higgs; and that Saville had been before convicted of felony.

THOMAS JONES . I am in the employ of Richard Turner Higgs, a draper, at Stratford. On the 28th of Feb. I placed a roll of calico on the steps inside the lobby of the door—it was on a wooden roller, and I had put a mark on it—this is the roller—(looking at it)—I missed the calico the next morning, when Mr. Higgs told me of it—there were sixty yards of it.

JOSEPH STAINS . I am a painter. On the evening of the 28th of Feb. I was passing Mr. Higgs' shop—I observed the two prisoners standing together at the corner of his shop, and talking together, I believe, but I was not close enough to hear them—I passed a little way, then turned my head, and saw some person currying the roll of calico across the road under their arm.
Saville. Q. Why did you not immediately go to Mr. Higgs and tell him? A. I did not know it was Mr. Higgs's—I had noticed the prisoners standing there, but I did not notice any calico as I passed.

RACHEL RAINER . I deal in marine stores, and live at Stratford, opposite Mr. Higgs. On the 28th of Feb. the prisoners came to my shop between seven and eight o'clock in the evening, and asked me to buy a roll of calico—I would not have anything to do with it—they then asked me to lend them a bag to put it in—I declined—they threw the roll of calico into the yard, I believe, but I did not see it—they left the roller in our yard—I saw it that night—I did not see it brought in the next morning, but I saw it on the fire, and the policeman came and took it out of the fire.
WILLIAM POTTER (police-constable K 273.) I went to Rainer's and found the roller in the fire—I took it out and showed it to Mr. Jones, who identified it—I had taken the prisoners before.
Lewis. When he took us he would not tell us what it was for; I did not know till I got to the station. Witness. I did tell them.

Saville. If it had been any other policeman they would have found the calico in Rainer's house; these policemen are drinking in her house when they ought to be on duty; she had been up here two or three times against boys for robbing.

COURT to R. RAINER. Q. Why did you not go to Mr. Higgs's? A. I was just putting my children to bed when I told the prisoners to take the calico away—I did not see it—it was on my premises a quarter of an hour—I could have gone to Mr. Higgs's—they had come and carried it off before my husband gave information.

JOSEPH BENTON (police-constable K 181.) I prodoce a certificate of Saville's former conviction, which I got at Mr. Clark's office—(read—Convicted the Srd of Feb., 1845, and confined ten days)—he is the person.

SAVILLE—
GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Six Months.

LEWIS—
GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Three Months.

984.
GEORGE BRAGG was indicted
for stealing 1 square, value 1s.; 1 plane, 3s.; and 1 adze, 2s.; the goods of
William King.

WILLIAM KING . I live in Speeding's-gardens, Poplar, and am a car
penter. I was working for Mr. Myers, on the other side of the water—I missed a square, a plane, and an adze—these are them.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Are there any marks on them? A. Here is a piece in this plane which I let in myself—I can swear to it.
WILLIAM JAMES LAWS . I am a pawnbroker—these tools were pawned by the prisoner on the 8th and 9th of Jan.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you remember his person? A. Yes, I knew him before.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Four Months.
(There were three other indictments against the prisoner.)

985.
DANIEL WASHBROOK and
JAMES GURNEY were indicted for
stealing 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
Edward Evans, from his person.

EDWARD EVANS . I live in Talbot-court, Gracechurch-street. On the 25th of March, about half-past three o'clock in the afternoon, I was at Greenwich, near the College-gate, looking at a man conjuring—I perceived nothing until the officer, who had both the prisoners in custody, showed me my handkerchief—this now produced is it—I know it was safe an hour before.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. There was a crowd round the conjuror? A. Yes, perhaps 100, or 150 people.

JOHN WHITE (police-constable R 108.) I was at Greenwich, and saw the prisoners by the College-gate—I followed them from the fair to the College—they were together—there was a crowd. I saw them go behind Evans, and saw Washbrook take the handkerchief from his pocket and hand it to Gurney—I secured them, and Glad win got the handkerchief.

WILLIAM GLADWIN (policeman.) I saw the prisoners by the prose
cutor—White took Washbrook, I took Gurney, and took this handker
chief out of his pocket.
Gurney's Defence. Washbrook told me he had picked up the handkerchief; he gave it to me and went away.
(The prisoners received good characters.)

WASHBROOK—
GUILTY . Aged 13.

GURNEY—
GUILTY . Aged 16.

986.
MOSES VAUGHAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of April, 1 purse, value 2d.; 2 half-crowns, and 2 pence; the goods of
William Lane, from his person; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.

987.
ELIZABETH GEORGE was indicted
for unlawfully obtaining, on the 22nd of Nov., half a sovereign, and other monies, of
Charlotte Melhuish, her mistress, by false pretences.
NOT GUILTY .

988.
ELIZABETH GEORGE was again indicted
for unlawfully obtaining, on the 8th of March, 1 half-sovereign, I half-crown, 2 shillings, 1 sixpence, and 4 pence; the monies of
Charlotte Melhuish, her mistress, by false pretences.

CHARLOTTE MELHUISH . I am a widow, and live in Park-grove, Black-heath. The prisoner entered my service last Aug.—I was in the habit of giving her money every week to pay the tradespeople—on the 8th of March I paid her 15s. 4s.—she gave me an account at that time, of what money she had paid, which I wrote down—among other things, here is, "Meat, 5s. 8d.; and beer, 2s. 3d."—that was written down by her dictation at the time; and, in consequence of her statement, I gave her half a sove
reign

and some shillings, making 15s. 4d., the amount she stated—I give her that money, believing she had paid the tradespeople for all those articles—Mr. Williams is my butcher, and Mr. Evans the publican—I desired her to deal with Evans.

HARRIET WILLIAMS . I am the daughter of John Williams, a butcher, in Spencer's-place, Blackheath—we supply the progenitrix with meat—the prisoner was in the habit of coming for it—I supplied her with meat the week before the 8th of March—there was 4s. 9d., due for that week, which has never been paid.

Prisoner. I paid you 10s. for a piece of beef and a leg of mutton that week. Witness. She paid for two joints that week, which came to 10s. 3 1/2d.—that was besides the 4s. 9d. that has not been paid—I did not deliver her meat to the amount of 4s. 9d. that week—I have a memorandum, which I made out the other day for the purpose of coming here—I did not deliver her meat to the amount of 4s. 9d. the week before the 8th of March—I cannot recollect whit she had that week—I know she had two joints, and those she paid for.

SARAH EVANS . I supplied the prosecutrix with beer, which my boy delivered to the prisoner at Mrs. Melhuish's house—4s. 4d. was due for the week before the 9th of March—I asked the prisoner that day to ask Mrs. Melhuish to pay the bills, which amounted to 2l. 10s. 2d., for beer delivered—she said Mrs. Melhuish was coming he me in a day or two, and she would pay it—she did not pay me 2s. 3d. that week—she paid me two sovereigns on the 16th of March
Prisoner. And I told you I would pay the other the moment I got it.

JOHN WATERS (police-constable R 177.) I took the prisoner into cus
tody—on going to the station she said she hoped I would call on Mr. Millington and Mr. Williams, and beg them to be her friends.

Prisoner's Defence. I never had more than half-a-sovereign, with which I paid the butcher's bill for a piece of veal and some beef; mistress had the bill and receipt; she owed me 11s., and I never bad it back again; she only allowed me 4s. a week to keep me, and, my health being bad, I was obliged to have a charwoman, and pay her; mistress was only at home two or three days a week, and the house was left solely to me, with lodgers; I had not the slightest idea of wronging any one of a halfpenny, and I should have paid all up if they had allowed me time.
I am sure that out of the 15s. 4d. which I paid her on the 8th of March 2s., 3d. was for beer.

GUILTY of obtaining the 2s. 3d. Aged 38.—
Confined Six Months.
(Mrs. Melhuish stated the amount altogether obtained by the prisoner to be 16l. or 17l.)

989.
WILLIAM HARRISON was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of March, 1 watch, value 5l. 10s., the goods of
Samuel Pearson, in a vessel on the navigable river Thames; and
JOHN CORMACK
, for feloniously receiving the same; well knowing it to have been stolen; to which

HARRISON pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Six Months.

SAMUEL PEARSON . I am mate of the brig Union. On Thursday, the 20th of March, she was lying in Bugsby's-hole, below Blackwall—Harrison was an apprentice belonging to the ship—about ten minutes past four o'clock, on the 19th of March, I came ashore, leaving him in charge of the

cabin—I returned about five, and he was pone—I saw him no more till he was in custody—I directly missed my watch, which 1 had left hanging on the starboard side of the cabin—I have never seen it since.
GEORGE SATCHELL . I am a seaman on board the Union. On the Thursday morning after this I met Harrison in Church-lane, and gave him in charge.

JOHN BURKE (police-constable H 81.) Harrison was given into my charge—he offered at the station-house to show me who he took the watch to if I took him to Cooper's-row—I did so, and Cormack was then appre
hended.

JOHN CONDON (policeman.) I went with Harrison to No. 2, Cooper's-alley, and saw Cormack sitting in the house—Harrison said, "That is the man I sold the watch to"—Cormack said he knew nothing of the watch or Harrison—the boy Norton was there, and said, "It is no use denying it; I saw him buy the watch at the straw yard; he gave 5s. for it."

JOSEPH NORTON . I have been sleeping in the straw-yard in Ratcliff-highway—I know Cormack—he slept in the same place—I saw Harrison and him together on a Wednesday evening, just by the fire-place, and heard Harrison say to Cormack that he had a watch to sell him—Cormack told him to keep it till the morning, and he would look at it—Harrison asked him 10s. for it—Harrison slept in the straw-yard that night—next morning they came into the room where they sell coffee—I then saw the watch, and took it in my hand—it was silver, with a little steel chain, and a seal, marked, "One penny"—I saw Harrison sell it to Cormack for 5s.—I saw the money pass—Cormack borrowed it from a man.

Cormack. Q. When did you see me with Harrison? A. On Wednesday night, just after they all went in—you borrowed the money of Joe Collier, who belongs to the Marine Society, and you paid him the money out of a sovereign.
S. PEARSON re-examined. There was a steel chain to my watch, a key, and a seal with "One Penny" marked on the lower part of it.

CORMACK—
GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Six Months.

990.
CHARLES WILTSHIRE was indicted
for stealing 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
William Rushton, from his person; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Three Months.

991.
SAMUEL DAVIS was indicted
for stealing 8 handkerchiefs, value 9s. 6d. the goods of
Alexander Murray Shepherd; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined Six Months.

992.
JOSEPH WHITELY was indicted
for assaulting
Mary Gouthart, with intent, &c.

GUILTY. of a Common Assault. Aged 19.—
Confined Six Months.

993.
HANNAH MCCARTHY was indicted
for stealing 1 pair of boots, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
John Slater.
ANTHONY TOOK . I am a shoemaker, and live at Deptford. These boots are John Slater's—I had them safe in my shop on the morning of

the 10th of March—the prisoner came that day for a pair of children's boots—she examined them outside the shop, brought them in, and asked the price—she left them on the counter, and went out—she was not out long before she passed the window again, took these boots, and ran away—I followed her—she was taken afterwards.

Prisoner. Q. Why not stop me? A. I had no one to mind my shop, or you would not have got from me—I saw you again on the Saturday night, and I made my boy pursue you to see where you went—I have no mark on these boots—I know I lost a pair like these.

JAMES HASTIE (policeman.) I went to the prisoner's lodging, and asked where the boots were—she said, "Here they are; I did not steal them"—in going to the station she said she bought them of a woman who travelled with a basket, but did not know where she lived—at the station she told the man she would give him the boots, and pay for the damage done to them—she said she had bought them on the Friday before the robbery.
Prisoner's Defence. My child had these boots to wear; I bought them of a poor widow, ten or eleven days before the prosecutor lost his.
THOMAS CAIRN . I am the prisoner's landlord. She brought down these boots to me on Sunday, the 2nd of March, and put them on the child's feet.
NOT GUILTY .

994.
GEORGE WILLIAMS and
EDWARD GILLETT were indicted for
stealing 1 handkerchief, value 6d.; 1 sixpence, 1 penny, and 7 halfpence; the property of
Rebecca Hart, from her person; to which

WILLIAMS pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Three Months.

REBECCA HART . I am single, and live in Giffin-street, Deptford. On the 24th of March, about six o'clock in the evening, I was in Greenwich fair—a policeman asked if I had lost my handkerchief, and I found I had—it had contained 10 1/2d.—this is it.

WILLIAM GLADWIN (police-constabit R 122.) I was at the fair—I saw the two prisoners together for half an hour—I saw them both attempt gentlemen's pockets, by putting their hands in, and feeling their pockets—I afterwards saw Williams put his hand into the prosecutrix's pocket, and take out this handkerchief—he was passing it to Gillett—I seized him, and it fell on the ground—I took both the prisoners, and took up the handkerchief, and found this money in it.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Was the fair crowded? A. It was—I was watching the prisoners—I saw them attempt to pick pockets, but not pick one before this—the people were not pushing about so much as they had been at the time this was taken—the prosecutrix was standing looking at a show.
(Gillett received a good character.)

GILLETT—
GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Three Months.

995.
DANIEL CUMMINGS and
THOMAS RUSSELL were indicted for
stealing, 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of
James Barber, from his person.

JAMKS BARBER . I am a printer. I went to Greenwich fair on the the 25th of March—an officer spoke to me, and I missed my handkerchief—he took the prisoners into a shop, and found my handkerchief on Russell—this is it.

JOHN WHITE (police-constable R 180.) I was at the fair, looking after thieves—I saw the two prisoners in company go behind the prosecutor—I had seen them together about half an hour—they stood by the side of each other—Russell put his right hand into the prosecutor's left-hand pocket, and took out his handkerchief—I took the prisoners, and between Russell's shirt and his skin I found the handkerchief. GEORGE MARTIN (police-constable R 93.) I was at the fair about two hours before this—I saw the prisoners together three or four different times—Russell attempted several pockets, and Cummings was close behind him—I took Cuminings, and found on him a pair of scissors and a tobacco-box.

CUMMINGS—
NOT GUILTY .

RUSSELL—
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

996.
HENRY CAVANNAGH was indicted
for stealing 1 sovereign, 1 half-crown, 1 sixpence, and 2 pence, the monies of
David Charles Smith, from the person of
Elizabeth Smith.

ELIZABETH SMITH . I am the wife of David Charles Smith—we live in Poplar-place, Lewisham—on the evening of the 17th of March I was in the gallery of Deptford Theatre, with my neighbours—I had a sovereign, a half-crown, a sixpence, and some coppers in my pocket—I held my pocket while I was in the gallery—I did not sit—I was standing—I felt a person crowd against me, and felt a sensation at my neck, which induced me to let go of my pocket—I did not miss my money till a quarter to ten, as I was going to leave the theatre, Mrs. Reed then said something to me, and then I missed my money—I saw the prisoner in the gallery—I came down and heard a scuffle—the prisoner passed me in going out—he made use of abusive language, and said, "You have lost nothing"—he was searched, and a half-crown, a sixpence, and two pence were found on him—there was no sovereign found, but he was seen to swallow something.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. I suppose the gallery was crowded where you were standing? A. No, it was not—there were a number of persons standing as well as I was—I did not go out to take any refreshment, nor take any next door before I went in.
