ALICE REED . I was with Mrs. Smith. I saw the prisoner close behind me—I saw my gown pulled up, and I missed 3s.—no one was with me but Mrs. Smith, and Mrs. Fell—we were standing—the prisoner was behind us very close, and I saw another man with him up in the gallery.
Cross-examined. Q. Was that other man near you? A. No, not that I saw—there were two or three other men—Mrs. Smith and I stood the whole time—we did not sit down, because we meant to leave.
MARY FELL . I went to the theatre with this party. I saw the prisoner standing behind us the whole evening—the policeman took him—I saw him swallow something.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you see him chewing anything before he swallowed anything? A. No—I do not know whether there is a staircase leading from the gallery to the public-house next door.
JOHN STEVENS . I was present when the prisoner was searched—I saw something pass from one side of his mouth to the other—I said, "He has something in his mouth"—he appeared to swallow it.
Cross-examined. Q. Had he a handkerchief round his neck A. I did not notice—his neck was not bare—there is a passage down from the gallery to the public-house.

GEORGE TELFORD (police-constable R 185.) I took the prisoner—I found on him a half-crown, a sixpence, one penny, and two halfpence—one of the halfpence is marked—the prosecutrix identified it—I saw the prisoner swallow something.

ELIZABETH SMITH
re-examined. I had a halfpenny that was peculiar—this is it—it is a harp halfpenny, and has a hole near the edge—the money found on the prisoner exactly corresponds with mine except the sovereign.
Cross-examined. Q. How lately before had you had that halfpenny? A. I took it at twelve o'clock that day—I did not spend any halfpence after that, nor take any change.

GUILTY .† Aged 23.—
Transported for Ten Years.

997.
ELIZA WOOTTON was indicted
for stealing 1 watch-key, value 10s.; 3 sovereigns, 1 half-sovereign, 1 shilling, and 1 groat; the property and monies of
Samuel Gregory, from his person.

SAMUEL GREGORY . I am a surgeon, and live at Greenwich. On the 26th of March, between eleven and twelve o'clock at night I met the pri
soner in Bridge-street, and went with her to a house—I gave her three or four shillings—I had between 3l. and 4l. in gold in my waistcoat pocket—I undressed, went to bed, and fell asleep—I awoke in about half au hour—she was then gone, and my money was gone—I bad been drinking.

Prisoner. He asked me to go with him to the Bee Hive, and we had three glasses of brandy and water; I felt myself getting giddy, and said I would go home to my father; he then took me to this house of ill-fame; he said he should like to have half an hour's sleep; he gave me the money, and I went out of the room; the woman said, "Are you going, what are you going to stand?" I gave her half-a-crown.

JOHN WHEEBLE (police-constable R 300.) I met the prosecutor about half-past one o'clock—I found the prisoner within fifty or sixty yards of her father's house—before I could say anything she ran away—I took her—she said, "I own I have robbed the gentleman, and I have the whole of the property in my purse, and the watch-key likewise"—I said, "Give it to me," and she did—she said, "I have only spent the money lie gave me to go with him;" and she told the inspector so.
Prisoner. No, he said, "You have robbed this gentleman;" I said, "I own I have it, but he gave it me."
NOT GUILTY .

998.
DENNIS MCCARTHY,
THOMAS DAVIS,
GEORGE JONES , and
JOHN DOUGHTY , were indicted for
stealing 1 pair of trowsers, value 25s., the goods of
William Watts; to which.

DAVIS pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Three Months.

HENRY JAMES KIGHTBBRIDE . I am in the employ of Mr. William Watts, a tailor and draper, in High-street, Deptford—this pair of are his—I saw them safe on a rail inside his shop, on the 29th of March, about half-past five o'clock in the afternoon—they are new, tad worth 25s.

JOHN WHITE (police-constable R 180.) On the 29th of March, I saw the four prisoners in High-street, Deptford—I watched them for an how, and about seven o'clock I saw the whole four of them go and stand within about three yards of Mr. Watts's shop—I then saw Jones and Doughty

cross the road, leaving the other two close to Mr. Watts's shop—in about five minutes I saw Davis coming from the shop, in company with M'Carthy, with the pair of trowsers—they crossed over to the other two, and they all walked away—as soon as they got away we took them—Davis had these trowsers—I took Doughty and Jones, and before I had said what I wanted them for, Doughty said, "We were not in company with the other two."

JOHN EVANS (police-constable R 190.) I was with White—I saw the prisoners in company together in High-street, for upwards of an hour—I then saw Davis put his hand in Mr. Watts's doorway, and pull something down, and walk away with M'Carthy—Jones and Doughty had crossed before—they could command a view of the shop, while Davis and M'Carthy were there—they were right opposite to it—Davis and M'Carthy crossed over to them—I took Davis and M'Carthy, and found the trowsers on Davis.
Jones's Defence. I was coming from Blackheath; I met this young man; we were going down the road, and the officer came and took hold of me and Doughty, and said it was for a pair of trowsers.
Doughty's Defence. My father sent me down to look for a ship; I came back, and met this lad; he asked me where I was going, I said, "To the highway, to cross the water."

MCCARTHY—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

JONES—
GUILTY . Aged 18.

DOUGHTY—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

999.
CHARLES PENTON and
ISAAC LOPAZ were indicted for
stealing 1 purse, value 6d.; 4 sixpences, and 1 farthing; the property of
Elizabeth Gleaves, from her person.

ELIZABETH GLEAVES . I am a widow and live in Caroline-street, Greenwich. I was standing on Greenwich-hill on the 24th of March, in the afternoon—I had a purse with four sixpences and a farthing in it—I had 3d. in coppers—this is my purse. JOHN CARPENTER (police-constable R 84.) I was on duty—I saw the two prisoners on the hill—I saw them go behind several females, and each of them try several pockets—I then saw Penton go behind Mrs. Gleaves—Lopaz was behind Penton, with his hands in his pockets, spreading out, and covering him—I then saw Penton lift up Mrs. Gleaves' dress, put his hand into her pocket, and take out this purse—I caught his hand—he dropped the purse, but I caught one farthing in his hand.
GEORGE CARPENTER . I was called by John Carpenter—I saw Penton throw the purse from his hand.

PENTON—
GUILTY . Aged 20.

LOPAZ—
GUILTY . Aged 31.

1000.
ELIZA DUNBAR was indicted
for stealing 3 half-sovereigns, 4 half-crowns, 8 shillings, and 2 sixpences; the monies of
Robert Seddon, from his person.

ROBERT SEDDON . I am a carpenter, and live at the railway station, New Cross, Deptford. In the middle of the afternoon, on the 31st of March, I was buying oranges near the Montague Arms at Deptford—the prisoner came up and asked if I would stand anything—we went to the Montague Arms, and were under a shed outside—I had three halt-sovereigns and other money in my pocket—she then took me to a room, where I suppose she lived, and sat down by the side of me—I then felt something come from

my trowsers pocket, and she stepped out of the door—I stood up, felt in my pocket, and my money was gone—I went out, but could not see the prisoner—I staid there till Mrs. Blogden came and asked me if I had had some money taken from me—she said the person had run round the corner.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. What time was this? A. About five in the afternoon—I walked half mile with her I dare say—we did not stop at one or two places before we got to the Montague Arms—I was sober—there was another woman with her at the Montague Arms—it was in her room I felt the money drawn from my pocket—there was no other woman with me in the room at the time my money was missing—I was not on the bed, but sitting on a chair—she did not gift me time to stop her hand in coming from my pocket—my money was safe not more than three quarters of an hour before; I had counted it over in coming along, and sepa
rated the gold from the silver in the street—the gold was in my waistcoat pocket and the silver in my trowsers—I felt nothing drawn from my waistcoat pocket—all my money was missing—I went down in the house for about five minutes to have something to eat, but that was before I missed the money—I did not meet any other girls below.

ELIZABETH HARWOOD . On the 31st of March the prisoner came by our door, and shook something in her hand like money, but I did not see It—she said to Mrs. Blogden, "You b—y w—"—she then turned to another person, and said, "I have picked him up, and we must cut."
Cross-examined. Q. Where were you? A. At my own door.

CHARLOTTE BLOGDEN . I saw the prisoner come up the street—she made a full stop, and shook something like money—she said to me, "You b—y w—," and then she turned to Brown, and said, "I have picked the b—up, and we must cut; I have got his rowdey. "

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined One Year.

1001.
ELIZA SIMPSON was indicted
for stealing 1 coat, value 18s., the goods of
Nathan Hart, her master.
NATHAN HART . I am a general dealer, and live at Woolwich. The prisoner was in my service—I lost a coat in Feb.—this is it.
WILLIAM LEACH . I am a pawnbroker. I took in this coat in pledge of the prisoner on the 17th of Feb., for 4s.
Prisoner. I pawned the coat, but it is not my master's.

NATHAN HART
re-examined. I can swear to the coat—here is my mark on it, which I put on it before I lost it.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Nine Months.
(There were two other indictments against the prisoner.)

1002.
JOHN HARRISON was indicted
for stealing 1 spoon, value 8s., the goods of
Harriet Denham and another.

HARRIET DENHAM . I am single, and have one partner—I live at Dept
ford. I lost some silver spoons—these are them—the prisoner was occasionally employed on my premises.

DAVID GRIMMETT . I am shopman to Mr. Tighe, a pawnbroker, at Deptford. I took in this spoon of the prisoner on the 7th of March, and another on the 17th of March—he said he brought them from his mother.
Prisoner. I know nothing about them.

GUILTY. Aged 24.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor. —
Confined Three Months.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

1003.
JOHN CLARKE and
HENRY HURRY were indicted for
steal
ing 33 panes of glass, value 1l. 10s.; and 7 glazed window-sashes, 5l.; the goods of
William Seaborn, and fixed to a certain building belonging to him; and that Hurry had been before convicted of felony.

WILLIAM SEABORN . I live at Camberwell. I am building twenty houses in Knacker's-lane, Lower-road, Deptford—I was there on the evening of the 27th of March, and left those premises all safe between six and seven o'clock in the evening—ten of the houses were glazed—I went the next morning between six and seven—I found I had lost some glass and frames—I found some of the frames had been taken out of the houses, and put in a field—I fetched them back, and missed seventy-five panes of glass from them—seven sashes had been taken from seven different houses—they were the sashes of the lower back rooms in each bouse—they had all been in their places the night before—the beads were in, but the lines were not—the sashes were kept in by the support of the beads—the frames were left across a garden field, not against the premises—these panes of glass fit exactly into ✗hese squares of the sash—there were six sashes of this size that I lost he✗his frame was one that was carried across the field—win
dow-frames a ✗ sorts of sizes—it is not very usual to see a square of glass fit into a ✗ as this does—you may go to a hundred shops and not find a square of glass to fit this frame.

WILLIAM NOAKES (police-constable M 104.) On the 27th of March I was on duty at a quarter before nine o'clock in the evening, in Russell-street, Bermondsey, which is a little more than a mile from Mr. Seaborn's, and met the two prisoners, one on each side of the way—they were coming in a direction from Mr. Seaborn's houses, and each carrying a bundle—I heard the glass make a noise—I stopped Clarke, and asked what he had got there—he said, "Glass"—I asked where he brought it from—he said from his master's, in High-street, Deptford—he men
tioned some name, which I do not recollect—he then said to Hurry, who was on the other side, "Give this officer one of our cards"—he then said, "Give him one of our governor's cards, it is all right"—Hurry took out a card or a piece of paper, but he did not give it to me, he put it into his pocket again—I then asked them both where they were going to take it to—they said, "To our governor's, in Blackfriars-road"—I took Clarke by the collar, to save the glass from falling—Hurry threw his bundle down, and ran away—on the road to the station Clarke said he did not know anything about the glass; the person who had ran away had given it to him to carry—I noticed a good deal of fresh putty on his hands, and he seemed to wish to get rid of something—I found this knife in his pocket, all over putty—I found about thirty-five panes of glass on Clarke—Hurry's bundle was picked up by a person standing by, at my request—that contained about forty squares of glass, but some of them were broken—I gave directions, and Hurry was taken afterwards.
JOHN WEST (police-constable M 249. I took Hurry on the 31st of March—I told him he was charged with being with Clarke—he said he did not know Clarke.
WALTER TYLER (City police-constable, No. 373.) I produce a certificate of Hurry's former conviction, which I got from the Clerk of the Peace of
Surrey—(read—Convicted 2nd of July, 1844, and confined Six month)—the prisoner is the person.

CLARKE—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

HURRY—
GUILTY . Aged 24.

1004.
JAMES POWER and
WILLIAM ABBOTT were indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Henry Harris, on the 8th of March, at Camberwell, and stealing therein 1 cloak, value 1l.; 4 gowns, 1l. 19s.; 2 sheets, 16s.; 1 apron, 1s.; and 1 pair of shoes, 4s.; his pro
perty.

ANN HARRIS . I am the wife of Henry Harris, of No. 5, Edmond-street, Camberwell. On Saturday night, the 8th of March, I left my house at twenty minutes after eight o'clock, leaving nobody in it—I left it all fastened up—I returned at ten minutes to nine—I found my front gate unbolted, which I had left bolted—all the doors and wint as✗ were fast as I had left them, but when I got in I found a lucifer on ✗ mat—I know nobody could have been in the house when I went out—it is a cottage all on one floor—there are hangings to my bed, but a person could not be concealed there—I went to light my candle, and found it was gone out of the candlestick—I went into my kitchen and found a mahogany caddy laid there broken open—it had been taken from under my bed in my bed-room—my box was open, and four gowns, two shawls, a cloak, an apron, a pair of shoes, and a pair of boots taken out—they had dropped one boot by the bedside—I saw all my property again, except the candle, the same night at the station—it is worth 4l.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Are there any valens to your bed? A. No—there are curtains—it is a tent bedstead—I have another bed in a little room, but that has no top—there arc sideboard cupboards—I had been in the house all day—I have no servant.

WILLIAM BOWMAN . I live at Walworth, a quarter of a mile from Mr. Harris—on Saturday night, the 8th of March, from a quarter to half-past eight, I saw both the prisoners together, nearly opposite Harris's house—Power went up against the door and came away from it again—I stopped for ten minutes watching them, and they came by me, just before I got to them, Power said to Abbott, "It is no use stopping here any longest is too late now, they won't come yet awhile"—I went into the Rose pub
lic-house, and spoke to a young man, then came out, and went up George-street to see for a policeman—I saw the prisoners standing under the win
dow of the Rose—I could not find a policeman—I came back, went into the Rose, and they were over by a shop window—they came acoss again, and stood under the Rose window—I met Davis, a policeman, and told him what I had seen.

Cross-examined. Q. How long did you lose sight of them? A. For an hour, after I came out of the Rose—I went about half-past tea o'clock to Harris's with the policeman—Mrs. Harris was at home then—I had not seen her go out.
Abbott. Q. Can you swear to me? A. swear to both of you.
by your dress and everything—I saw you both in custody at the station that night—you were strangers to me before.

JAMES BAKER (policeman.) On the 8th of March, from half-past eight to a quarter to nine o'clock, I saw the prisoners together and stopped them—Abbott had got a bundle—I went up to them, and asked Abbott what he had got there—Power answered, "I have got something for my mother," and said, Abbott was carrying it for him—I asked what it was—Power said he had brought it from Mr. Hawkins's, a confectioner, in Cam
berwell-road—I asked whereabouts—he said the other side of the green—I asked where there—he said leading away to Peckbam—I asked where he was going to carry it—he said to the Elephant and Castle—I asked where there—he said past Horsemonger-lane, the first turning on the right—I asked whether it was the house before he got to Horse
monger-lane—he said, "Yes"—I said there was no house, only a coach
maker's before you come to the lane, and I did not believe his story, I should take them to the station, and inquire whether it was true or not—Power said, "Will you go to the place with me?"—I said I did not be
lieve his statement—he said it was not far, and he was not going to pass the Elephant and Castle, he was going to turn down the New Kent-road—I asked whether he worked for Hawkins—he said he did—I asked for how long—he said for some little time, and it was Mr. Hawkins's brother he was going to take the clothes to—I asked what Hawkins's brother was—he said he could not tell me—I asked the name of the place where he lived—he said he did not know—I called Jones, a con
stable over, and we took them to the station with the handle—they said at first they would not go with me—we left them in charge of the in
spector, and I and Jones went to Camberwell to inquire for Hawkins, but could not find any such person—I saw the bundle opened at the station—it contained the articles stated—the prosecutrix saw and claimed them—Abbott said he was carrying them for Power.

CHARLES JONES (police-constable P 230.) I assisted in taking the pri
soners to the station—as we were going I asked Power where he got the things from—he said he had brought them from Mr. Hawkins, a confec
tioner at Camberwell, and was going to take them to Mr. Hawkins's bro
ther in Horsemonger-lane—I said it might be true, but I doubted it—he directly answered, "Oh, you are a very nice man; but I do not blame you if you can get a shilling or two by it."

RICHARD DAVIS (police-constable P 55.) I saw Bowman, and in con
sequence of what he said to me I went to Edmond-street, made inquiry, and found that Mrs. Harris's house had been robbed—(I had previously seen the prisoners and the bundle at the station)—I saw this boot on the bed at Mrs. Harris's—I said I had every reason to believe that the fellow boot was at the station—I took possession of it—this tea-caddy was broken open.
MRS. HARRIS re-examined. The articles in this bundle are nine, and were in my box when I went out that night.

Cross-examined. Q. When you got home was your door open? A. No, I found it locked as I had left it—I unlocked it—there was no other mode of getting into the house—I have back windows, but they were all fastened—I examined every one when I came home.

COURT. Q. What parish is Camberwell in? A. St. Giles's, Camber
well, it is called—I always understood it to be St. Giles's, Camberwell.

RICHARD DAVIS
re-examined. I have been on the heat fifteen years, and always understood it to be St. Giles's, Camberwell, never any other way.

Abbott's Defence. I went into the Walworth-road about seven, o'clock in the evening, and went as far as Camberwell-green, and turned into no turning out of the open road until the policeman took me; I met Power; I had seen him before, but was not in his company much; he asked where I was going; I said, "Home;" I walked with him a good bit; he asked me if I would carry the bundle for him, as his hand was cold; I asked where he was going; he said he had a job to carry it for a gentleman at Camberwell to Horsemonger-lane; I said I would carry it as far as the Elephant and Castle, and then leave him; I carried it until the policeman stopped me; I have been in the habit of going to sea.
(Power received a good character.)

POWER—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

ABBOTT—
GUILTY . Aged 20.

p.hi:
Of larceny only.—
Confined Two Years.

div1.p:
1005.
RICHARD SLADE was indicted
for burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Harriet Foreman, on the night of the 7th of March, at St. George the Martyr, with intent to steal, and stealing therein 1 scarf, value 1l.; 1 boa, 5s.; and 1 bonnet, 5s.; the goods of
Caroline Willis: 1 habit-shirt, value 1s., the goods of
Fanny Jones: and 1 pair of cuffs, value 4d., the goods of
Frances King; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. (Aged 28.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Twelve Months.

1006.
JAMES HERBERT was indicted
for feloniously assaulting
William Girling on the 27th of March, and cutting and wounding him in and upon his head, with intent to murder him:—2nd COUNT, stating his intent to be to disable:—3rd COUNT, to do some grievous bodily harm.

WILLIAM GIRLING . I am a shoemaker, and live at No. 12, Nelson's
place, Locksfields. The prisoner is married to my niece—he is a shoe
maker, and lodged with me up to Thursday, the 27th of March—hs came home about a quarter to two o'clock that day—I think he was in liquor—I went down to his room and asked if he had any rent for me—he owed me 7s. rent—he said he had none for me—I said it was not likely that he would have any, for he had been out three days previous, and had not been at work, he had been losing his time so, idling about—I told him I would forgive him the rent be owed me if he would go out of my place—he said I could not afford to lose it, and he should not go until he had paid me—I said I thought I was authorised to put his things outside the door—he said he knew the law as well as me, I must not put them out, if I did I should find him a different man to what he was (he had been a very quiet well conducted man before) my wife was there, and portion of his furniture and put it out at the door—I think it was a child's chair, and another chair—when she came in again he went over towards her—I said, "Jem, do not strike my wife"—he had not lifted his hand to strike her at that moment, but I thought he was about to do so—I cannot say whether I pushed a table up against him, or whether I did not, or whether he thought I intended to strike him, but he took up a hammer

and struck me with it on the head—I cannot say that he struck me more than once—it stunned me—I cannot say whether I lost my senses or not, but I heard my wife scream; that brought me to myself—I was bleeding—I went over to Mr. Dry, the surgeon—he dressed my head—I was bleeding all the way I went—I walked home again, and went to bed—I kept my bed for a week, without getting up—I am a great deal better now, quite nicely—it was a shoemaker's hammer he struck me with—it was in the room where he worked, and the hammer laid down before him—I have known him from a boy, I should say twelve or fourteen years—he always behaved very quiet—that was his character up to the time he struck me.

ELEANOR GIRLING . I am the wife of William Girling. I remember the prisoner coming home on Thursday—he has two children—the eldest little girl was in my room when he came home—he spoke from one room to the other to the child, and asked her what business she had with me—I said I took her in out of good nature, as he had left her with a fire in the room—I afterwards went into the room when my husband was there—I began to remove a chair or two from the room—when I came back, I laid my hand on a tea-board—I did not see the prisoner come towards me, but I heard my husband say, "Don't strike my wife!"—I saw my husband standing still—the prisoner took up a hammer, and struck him one blow—I screamed and threw my arms round my husband's neck—he seemed to reel, and put his hand to his head—he did not fall—the prisoner stood still—I took up a little chair, and tried to strike him with it—he threw up the window, and told the people outside what rent he owed—he remained abont the place a little while, and then went away—he said he would not strike me—I could not see whether my husband's head bled, for my sight seemed to leave me, I was so frightened.

GEORGE WESTON (policeman,) I was sent for to Mr. Dry's about a quarter past two o'clock—I found him dressing Girling's head, which was bleeding very much—I went home with him—I was shown into a shoe
maker's room by his wife, and found this hammer up in one corner of the front parlour—there were four or five hairs on the sharp part of it—there was a quantity of blood about the room—the prisoner was not there.

HENRY DRY . I am a surgeon. Girling came to me about two o'clock in the afternoon—he had two incised wounds in the head, over the left eye—the sharp edge of this hammer might have inflicted them—a branch of the temporal artery was severed by it, and a considerable quantity of blood lost—he has been under my care ever since, and is not well yet—I think he will do well—it is impossible to say whether he may not suffer permanently from it—the wound is of that character that weeks and months might elapse before any symptom might present itself—I do not think him out of danger—when before the Magistrate, I called it a dangerous wound—it must have been inflicted by two blows, for the upper wound is longitudinal, and the other transverse.

WILLIAM MORTON (policeman.) I apprehended the prisoner in a little street leading into Suffolk-street, Borough, on the 27th of March, about half-past nine o'clock in the evening—I told him the charge against him was for assaulting Mr. Girling—he said, "Assaulting! what, in my own place?"—I said, "Yes"—on going to the station, he said, "They cannot hang me up by the heels, and what they give me I shall be able to bear"—next
morning, outside the court, he said he was striking at nis arm, he did not mean to hit his head, but his hammer slipped.

WILLIAM GIRLING
re-examined. This hammer belongs to the prisoner—it is the hammer I was struck with—I was not in the room when he came home—I did not see any pudding in the room.

ELEANOR GIRLING
re-examined, I did not see any pudding in the room—I could not see whether his hands were greasy.

Prisoner's Defence. I owed Girling 9s.; he asked me for it; he stid, "Take your things away;" I said, "No, I will not take them away till I have paid you; you cannot afford to lose the rent more than I can;" with that his wife took two chairs, and a tea-board outside the door; he ran In and took the table up, and was in the act of turning it out; I took up the hammer, and was going to strike him on the arm, but it slipped out of my hand.

MR. DRY re-examined. There was an inch between the two wouods, and you never get a longitudinal and a transverse wound at the same time—one must have been done when he was on the right side, and the other when on the left, and he had a contused wound on the right arm, so there must have been three blows—the wound on the arm was fresh.

WILLIAM GIRLING
re-examined. I had received no wound on my arm before I entered the room—all the injury was done after I entered the room.

GUILTY on the 3rd COUNT. Aged 24.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor. —
Confined Twelve Months.

1007.
JOHN BUTLER was indicted
for a rape.
NOT GUILTY .

1008.
JOHN MURPHY and
EDWARD SULLIVAN were indicted for
burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Charles Pitcher, about three in the night of the 29th of March, at St. George the Martyr, Southwark with intent to steal, and stealing therein, 1 coat value 5l.; 1 musical-box, 1l. 10s.; 1 pocket-book, 2s.; and 1 spoon, 1s.; his property.

MURPHY pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 25.

SULLIVAN pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 25.
(Sullivan received a good character.)

1009.
CYRUS SYMES was indicted
for burglariously breaking and en
tering the dwelling-house of
Harriet Curtis, at Battersea, about four in the night of the 4th of April, with intent to steal, and stealing therein, 1 tea chest, ralue 5s.; 1 work-box, 5s. 6d.; 1 clock, 6s.; the goods of
James Mullinger: and 1 work-box, value 3s. 6d. the goods of Harriet Curtis; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months
(The prisoner received an excellent character.)

1010.
JOHN PICKERING was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of April, 1/4 of a yard of lasting, value 8d.; and 1/4lb weight of leather, 6d. the goods of
Henry Tune, his master.

HENRY TUNE . I am a shoemaker, and live in Blackfriars-road. The prisoner was in my employ for nearly twelve months, and worked on the premises as a clipper—he had no authority to take any work or anything off the premises—on Friday evening, the 4th of April, he left my house about five minutes past eight o'clock, at his usual time—in consequence of suspicion I sent for him to come back, and told him I suspected he had some property on him belonging to me—he at first denied it—I sent for a policeman, and while he was gone for he pulled a piece of leather out of his pocket, with a piece of something else, and said that was all he had got, and he hoped I should forgive him—he placed it upon the table—it was my property—it had my mark upon it—I afterwards saw him searched at the station, and some lasting found on him which he had no authority to take—these are the things produced—I afterwards went to his lodgings and found a great quantity of materials of every description belonging to me—he had not the slightest authority to take them—he had 16s. a week.
ALEXANDER HAUGHEY (policeman,) I took the prisoner into custody on the 4th of April—I searched him at the station, and found this lasting on him.

p.hi: The prisoner put in a petition confessing his guilt, pleading poverty, and imploring mercy for the sake of his wife and children.

div1.p:
GUILTY . Aged 35.—
Confined Six Months.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

1011.
WILLIAM BENBOW was indicted
for stealing 1 handker
chief, value 3s., the goods of
William Harding Birchall, from his person.

WILLIAM HARDING BIRCHALL . I have an office in Newgate-street. On Sunday evening, the 22nd of March, between six and seven o'clock, I was walking in the London-road—the witness Goldsmid came and touched me on the shoulder—in consequence of what he said, I felt in my outside coat pocket, and missed a silk handkerchief, which I had safe not a minute before—it has never been found.

JOSEPH GOLDSMID . I live at Newington-causeway. On Sunday even
ing, the 22nd of March, I was in the London-road, and saw two boys—I saw one of them pick the prosecutor's pocket of a handkerchief—I cannot swear it was the prisoner, or that he was one of the two—they ran away—I was on the opposite side of the way—I was examined before the Magis
trate—the signature to this deposition is mine—(looking at it.)

Q. Listen to this, "I saw the prisoner take from the prosecutor's hind pocket a blue handkerchief with white spots; I know him by sight quite well; I have been in the habit of seeing the prisoner for the last twelve
month, and I am quite certain he is the person that took the prosecutor's hand
kerchief." Witness. My not swearing to him now is in consequence of passing through a field, and observing, among other boys assembled there for the purpose of gambling, a person resembling the prisoner so much, that I can
not swear to him now—when before the Magistrate I laboured under the delusion that it was him; but seeing another lad so like him, I cannot conscientiously swear to him.
NOT GUILTY .

1012.
ELIZA JOHNSON was indicted
for stealing 1 watch, value 2l.; 1 guard-chain, 10s.; 1 watch-key, 1d.; and 1 handkerchief, 1s.; the goods of
William Bland, from his person.

WILLIAM BLAND . I am in the Royal Artillery. I was at Richmond, recruiting—on the 31st of March, about nine o'clock in the evening, I met the prisoner in the street, and went with her to the Magpie public-house, for about an hour, drinking with her—I had my watch in my watch-pocket—I had not my belt on—I afterwards came out, walked about with her till about twelve o'clock, and then went back with her to the Magpie—she left, and after she was gone I missed my watch—there were other persona in the Magpie besides her—I had taken my watch out, and put it into an
other pocket by my side—I am sure I had it when I first left the Magpie with her—I had not been in any other house with her—this is my watch.

WILLIAM MILLICHAP (police-constable V 33.) At a quarter before one o'clock in the morning, on the 1st of April, I met the prosecutor—he was not sober—he gave me information, and I went after the prisoner—I found her in Cleaver-street, Richmond, the next morning—she said she had not been in Richmond the evening before, she had been to Hampton fair, dancing with some soldiers there, and had just returned—when I first saw the prosecutor he was dozing, and when I spoke to him he told me of his loss—his jacket was unbuttoned, and his trowsen a little unbuttoned, and his braces hanging down behind him—I took him home, and put him to bed—he was stupidly drunk.

HENRY HOLLAND (police-constable V 122.) I saw the prisoner with the prosecutor that night in George-street, Richmond, about 300 yards from the Magpie—I afterwards saw her about a quarter past twelve o'clock—she was running—a man called to her, and she said she could not stop—I afterwards saw the prosecutor coming up an alley, very tipsy—he could scarcely walk—I then met Millichap, and we found the prosecutor sitting down near the road—we lifted him up, and took him home—I do, not believe he knew what he was about.
MARY ANN GRORGE . I searched the prisoner at the station.—I found on her this watch and guard, and silk handkerchief—she said, "That is the watch."
Prisoner's Defence. He said he had spent all his money, and he, left me his watch till the next day; the handkerchief he gave me.
NOT GUILTY .

1013.
JOHN CLARKE
was indicted for stealing 1 watch, value 4l. 10s.; and 1 watch-guard, 10s.; the goods of
William Cresford, from his person.

WILLIAM CRESFORD . I am a ship-carpenter, and live in East-street, Commercial-road. On the 24th of March, about nine o'clock at night. I went into a public-house in the Borough—I called for some gin and water—I was the worse for liquor when I went in—after I had been there a short time I saw the prisoner and others come in front of the bar—I found myself very much the worse for liquor, and I left the house—I had not got twenty yards before some person came and asked me to go back and have something more to drink—I refused—he gave me a shove—I fell, and felt him draw my watch and guard from me—the watch was in my pocket, and the guard over my neck—I got up as well as. I could, and called, "Stop thief!"—I lost sight of the person, but I went on. and met the policeman coming back with the prisoner—I went to the station, and soon after saw my watch and guard brought in by a female—this is it—it
was snatched from me a little after nine, and it was brought to the station between nine and ten, to the best of my recollection.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Do you recollect whether you went with any woman? A. I have a very imperfect recollection of what happened.

EDWARD OXLEY CLARKE . On the night of the 24th of March I was coming from the Borough-market—I passed St. Thomas-street, about half-past nine o'clock—the prisoner brushed by me, and at the same mo
ment I heard the prosecutor call out, "Stop thief!" and he seemed stum
bling—I turned to run after the prisoner—he turned at the back of St. Saviour's church—the policeman, hearing the cry, caught him—I am sure he is the man that I saw running from the prosecutor.

Cross-examined. Q. What are you? A. A shop ticket-writer—I was not examined by the Magistrate, but was subpcenaed here by the policeman—I could not have been above three yards from the prisoner—he ran fast, and was stopped at the corner of Winchester-street—I live at No. 1, Fountain-court, in the Minories.

ELIZABETH MADDERS . I live at No. 6, Winchester-street. About ten o'clock at night, on the 24th of March, I was sitting in the parlour, and heard a noise—I went out, saw the prisoner running, and saw his left hand move at the corner of Winchester-street, just after you pass St. Saviour's church—I went to that spot, at the corner of the street where I saw his hand move, and found this watch—I took it to the station.

Cross-examined. Q. What are you? A. I am single; I live with my father, who is a tinman—when I went out I saw the prisoner in cus
tody of a constable—it was while he and the constable were going along that I saw him make the motion with his hand.

Q. Did you not say you saw him running, and make a motion with bis hand? A. Yes, so I did, but it was after the policeman had got him, and they were going along together—I assist my father in his business.

THOMAS MOORE (police-sergeant M 11.) I saw the prisoner running in Winchester-street—I took him—Madders brought this watch, which I produce—the prisoner went by the corner of Winchester-street, where this watch was found.

GUILTY.* Aged 20—
Transported for Ten Years.

1014.
FREDERICK COLE was indicted
for embezzling 1l. 8s. the monies of
Samuel Williams, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

1015.
DAVID MCKIBBIN was indicted
for embezzling 2l. 9s. 6d., the monies of
John Peel, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Four Months.

1016.
ESTHER GILBERT was indicted
for stealing 2 collars, value 1s.; 1 handkerchief, 6d.; 1 cap, 3d., and 1 1/2 yards of ribbon, 1d.; the goods of
Barbara Stratton: and 1 pair of ear-rings, value 4s., the goods of
Diana Oliver.

BARBARA STRATTON . I am single, and live as cook to Mr. Lionel Oliver, at Wimbledon. I lost these collars and other things—these ear-rings are Miss Diana Oliver's—the prisoner lived servant there, but left.

JOSEPH MOUNT (police-constable C 128.) I went to No. 8, Stean's
gardens, Piccadilly—I found the prisoner there, and in a box which she gave me the key of, I found all these things.

GUILTY. Aged 21.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Three Months.

1017.
JAMES PARSONS was indicted
for stealing 27 deals, value 3l. 10s.; and 57 wooden planks, 9l.; the goods of the Company of pro
prietors of the
Grand Surrey Canal.—2nd COUNT, stating them to be the goods of
Charles Walton and others.

WILLIAM PETERS . I am in the employ of the Grand Surrey Canal Company. On the 6th of March my attention was called to the deals—there ought to have been forty-six—I found by the book there were forty
three deficient—I did not make the entry in the book, but I saw the deals after they were entered, and I had sold several parcels from that pile—there was a pile of 147, and fifty-five and forty-fix had been delivered—the rest, which had been sold to Mr. Scarf, remained—I saw them safe on the 4th of March, and missed forty-three of them on the 6th—I then went to look at sixteen which I had sold to Mr. Hinton, and out of tkem I missed four
teen—I missed in all fifty-seven planks and forty-three deals, eighty-four pieces in all—I went to Archer's Wharf, and saw a punt lying there, which I had seen the day before four or five ships dowa, and the eighty-three pieces of wood were on the brick-wall—they were the pieces I had seen safe on the premises of the Canal Company on the Tuesday before—I saw the prisoner shortly after, on Mr. Archer's wharf in custody—I said I was sorry to see him there—he said, "I only hired the punt for Johnson"—I knew the prisoner—I cannot tell whether he was employed on the water.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLAMTINE. Q. What did you go to the book for? A. I knew the deals were missing, and I went to see if anybody else had delivered any of them—I could not have ascertained that feet without the book, because I am not the foreman—the delivery-book is not here—Griffiths and three or four others have a right to deliver goods—they take orders, and go and mark off the goods—I have never been what I call suspended—I would rather not mention what it was.

WILLIAM LANGPORD . I am a lighterman. On the 3rd of March the prisoner and Harwood came to me—Harwood said the prisoner wanted a punt—I said mine was stolen, but I could get them one for 3s.—the pri
soner said, "The old man will not mind 3s."—I showed them Patey's punt, and they said it was too big for them, they wanted one of twelve or fourteen feet for scaffolding boards—they both Baid the little one would do—I took the punt, and put her into the canal, and made her fast—the prisoner said, "Take her below the ships, and I will leave you a pint of ale at the Bull"—he said Harwood would take charge of her—that wat on the Wednes
day, and on Thursday I saw Harwood, who came that morning from Blackheath with the old gentleman—he said he had taken a punt from the Commercial Docks with a short 100 of deals in it, and he had turned them into the punt that I took up, I should find the punt at Smith's Lock.

WILLIAM PETBRS
re-examined. Q. You say Griffiths and several other persons might deliver deals? A. Yes, but they could not deliver these, because they were stolen—they are not here, and the book is not here.
NOT GUILTY .

1018.
GEORGE FOGG was indicted
for embezzlement.
SARAH FARRELL . I deal with Mr. Thomas Yates. On the 28th of March I paid the prisoner 3s. 6d. for his master, for meat which I had had at different times.
ANN EVANS . I paid the prisoner, on the 29th of March, 2l. 4s. 9 1/2d. for his master, on account of my mistress—I am quite sure of it.

THOMAS YATES . I am the prisoner's master. On the 28th of March I did not receive 3s. 6d. from Sarah Farrell, nor on the 29th of March, 2l. 4s. 9 1/2 from Ann Evans—I am quite clear I did not receive either of them—he ought to pay me every day.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. How long had he been in your service? A. About a year and a half—he has sometimes paid money to my wife, when I was out of the way—he was taken upon the 2nd of April.

COURT. Q. Have you demanded this money of him? A. No, not till he was given into custody—on the Wednesday morning my little boy brought me a book, which was to be made up and returned—the prisoner told me he had received the money—the book and money had been sent by him on the 29th—this is the book which I sent as a bill—the book was to be returned immediately, and he kept it till the Wednesday morning.
NOT GUILTY .

1019.
GEORGE FOGG was again indicted
for embezzlement.
JANE TRACEY . I paid the prisoner 10s. on the 31st of March, for his master for meat.

THOMAS YATES . The prisoner was my servant—I did not receive 10s. from him on the 31st of March—I never received 10s. from him on account of Mrs. Tracey—my wife is in the habit of receiving money from the pri
soner—on Tuesday morning, the 1st of April, I said to the prisoner, "Ask Mrs. Tracey for money," and he said, "Very well"—my wife is not here—she is not able to attend—no conversation has passed between her and me in the prisoner's presence about this money.
NOT GUILTY .

1020.
CATHERINE HALL was indicted
for stealing 1 pair of boots, value 4s., the goods of
George Ashwood, from the person of
Sophia Esther Ashwood; and that she had been before convicted of felony.

SOPHIA ASHWOOD . I am the wife of George Ashwood—I have a little girl four years old, named Sophia Esther Ashwood—I sent her out on the 4th of April with a pair of boots on—she came back without them—I gave information, and the officer brought the prisoner—the child said it was her that took her boots—the prisoner said, "I never saw you, I could not take your boots," and then she said, "Yes, I did take them, and sold them to a woman at the foot of Westminster-bridge, for 4d."

THOMAS BALDWIN (police-sergeant L 13.) I heard of this, and saw the prisoner standing against the station door—I asked her name—she said Catherine Hall—I compared her with the description in the book, and took her to Mrs. Ashwood, in Lambeth-walk—she said her mother had turned her out of doors, and she had taken the boots, and sold them to a woman.
JAMES PORTER (police-constable D 55.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's conviction—(read.)

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Six Months.

1021.
JOHN BALL was indicted for
stealing 1 10l. bank-note the mo
nies of
Henry Flower; and
EDWARD LEWIS and
SAMUEL LEWIS
, for feloniously receiving the same, knowing it to be stolen.

HENRY FLOWER . I am managing clerk to Messrs, Goding and Co., brewers, in Belvedere-road, Lambeth. Ball was employed about their premises in Nov. last—he was to wait on the clerks, and go on errands or messages for them—in Nov. last I had a 10l. note of my own, which I put into a drawer in the strong closet in the brewery—Ball bad access to that closet—the key of the drawer was on a bunch of keys which was in the closet—I missed the note on my return from Dover, about the 20th of Nov.—it had been safe two or three days before.

ROBERT FENNING (police-constable L 181.) On the 24th of Feb. I went to Goding's brewery—I saw Ball—Mr. Goding sent for him to the counting-house—I cautioned him not to say anything, and I said I was to take him for some other things—I named the, 10l. note—he said he bad not taken it—he afterwards said something, and I fetched Harvey to the station—Harvey said in Ball's presence that Ball had taken a 10l. note and brought it to Lewis—Ball denied it—Harvey said, "You know you brought the 10l. note and another note, and received 6l. for it, you may as well tell the truth, for I shall"—nothing further passed.

JOHN PETER PERRY . I am clerk at Lambeth Police-court. When Ball was brought up for examination he said, (reading) "What he says (meaning Harvey) is right; they gave me 6l. for the 10l. and 5l. notes, but asked me for 3l. back, because they said they could not change the 10l. note."Harvey says," When Ball came for the 6l. I was there; he told me that he had a 5l. note and a 10l. note, and sold them for 6l."
Ball. James Halnut came up with Harvey, and told me to say what Harvey said, but what Harvey said was not true.

WILLIAM HARVEY . I am fourteen years old. I was in the service of Edward and Samuel Lewis till they were taken into custody—I know Pall quite well—I have seen him at Lewis's lodgings, at No. 3, Artichoke-court, Lambeth—I have seen Ball there in a morning, and the Lewis's were up in a corner whispering about notes, and in going up the Cut one night Ball said to me, "I sold Samuel Lewis a 5l. note and a 10l. note for 6l., and be made me give him 3l. back, he said there was one note bad, and he could not change it"—I heard the Lewis's say up in the room that Ball had got a 5l. note and a 10l. note, and "I will take them to Bill to change them"—Edward and Samuel Lewis both said that—Samuel Lewis sent me one night to Ball to get some money—he told me to tell Bali that Edward was ill, and he wanted some money—Ball told me he got the notes from Mr. Goding's brewery, and another thing he told me that he took a check off Mr. Goding's table, and he said it was a g-s shame that the Lewis only gave him 6l. for the notes, and made him give them 3l. back.

Samuel Lewis. Q. Did you ever see Ball give me a 5l. note? A. No, but you and Edward Lewis went up in a corner and whispered about notes—I used to see Ball at your place very often—you was not at work at Mr. Starling's when Ball came up—you did not work at Mr. Starling's while I was with you, which was eight, or nine, or ten week-Ball tow me he brought the notes one day—you, and I, and Edward Lewis were there when Ball came up—you called him in the corner, and whispered to
him—we had not long got up—he brought a basket, and put it down by the window.

Samuel Lewis. I never had the notes—I worked at Mr. Starling's from the 11th of Nov. till after Christmas—my brother told me that Harvey had been at Union-hall. Witness. I never was taken up in my life for anything.

BALL—
GUILTY. Aged 12.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Three

EDWARD LEWIS—
GUILTY . Aged 12.—
Confined Three Months.

SAMUEL LEWIS—
GUILTY . Aged 18.—(See the next case.)

1022.
WILLIAM HENRY WARREN was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of Feb., 12ozs. weight of India-rubber, value 1s. the goods of
Charles Kay, and another, his masters; and the said
SAMUEL LEWIS and
EDWARD LEWIS
for feloniously receiving the same, well know
ing it to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

BENJAMIN NICHOLLS . I live in York-street, Lambeth, and am manager to Charles Kay and another—Warren had been in their employ, and was discharged—they have lost some India-rubber—I have examined that which is produced, and I believe it belongs to my masters—there is no mark on this, but in the place where Warren worked, there were 300 or 400 of such pieces, and he had an opportunity of taking it.

WILLIAM HARVEY . I was living with the Lewis's, in Artichoke-court—I know Warren by his coming to dine in their room, petty nearly every day—he used to have it brought to him ready cooked by his mother—there was only myself living with the Lewis's—I had my lodging there—one Thursday at dinner-time Warren brought up an India-rubber bottle, and gave it to Samuel Lewis, who looked at it, and said, "Very well," and chucked it under the bed—I believe Edward Lewis was out—I only saw Warren bring one piece of rubber.
CHARLES STEWART (police-constable L 185.) On the 22nd of Feb. I went to Lewis's lodgings—Fenning found one of these bottles of rubber under the bed, and the other in the box.

ROBERT FENNING (police-constable L 181.) I found this bottle of rubber under the bed, and this other in the box—I took Warren—I told him I wanted him for some India-rubber—he said it was all right, his father had seen. Mr. Nicholls, and settled it—I said, no, he had not, for I had just come from there—he then said he had taken one, and no more.
Warren. I did not say so.

WARREN—
GUILTY. Aged 15.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Three Months.

SAMUEL LEWIS—
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Transported for Seven Years.

EDWARD LEWIS—
NOT GUILTY .

1023.
GEORGE ANSELL was indicted
for stealing 1 pair of boots, value 6s. 6d., the goods of
John Hopkins.
JOHN HOPKINS . I am a shoemaker. I lost a pair of boots—these are them—the prisoner was at my house continuously.
CAROLINE MUGGERIDGE . The prisoner came to me on Friday night, the 28th of March, at half-past ten o'clock, and gave me this pair of boots.
EDEN BIGGS . I am apprentice to the prosecutor. The prisoaer left his house about eight o'clock that evening.
Prisoner's Defence. I had promised this young woman a pair of Boots; I thought I would take them, and pay for them on Saturday.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Three Months.

1024.
ANN ELIZABETH BROWN was indicted
for stealing 1 shawl, value 3s., the goods of
Samuel Beale, and another.

JOHN LEE . I am in the service of Samuel Beale, and another—they are pawnbrokers. I was watching outside the shop on the 17th of March—the prisoner and another female came up, and commenced looking at a shawl—the other held up a table-cloth—I looked over it, and saw the pri
soner take up a shawl which was outside, and put it under her own shawl, but seeing me noticing her, she threw it down and went away—she re
turned in about five minutes—there were then several females standing together—she went behind them, put her hand between them, and drew the shawl off the box it was on—she went off about twenty or thirty yards with it—I went and took her—this is the shawl—she had it under her own.

GUILTY .* Aged 32.—
Confined Nine Months.

1025.
WILLIAM HEATH and
ALFRED WRIGHT were indicted for
stealing 80 lbs. weight of coals, value 1s., the goods of
Henry Philip Davis; and that Heath had been before convicted of felony.
RICHARD ADAMS . I am watchman to Mr. Henry Philip Davis—he had a barge with coals in it. off Palace-yard, Lambeth—that is the barge the officer saw—the coals in it were my master's.

JAMES FROST (police-constable L 59.) I was on duty about eight o'clock in the evening, on the 25th of March, in Palace-yard, Lambeth—I saw the prisoner by the side of Mr. Davis's barge—I saw Heath lift Wright into the barge, and Wright rolled some coals to the side, he gave them to Heath, who took them, and they were removed fifteen of sixteen yards from the barge.

Heath. I was going over the water, and when I got there, the officer took me; this little boy could not lift the coals; they weighed 601bs. Witness. One coal weighed 60 lbs., Wright rolled to the side, and Heath took it down.
Wright. I was not near the barge.

SAMUEL HOCKDAY (police-constable L 178.) I produce a certificate of Heath's former conviction, which I got from the Sessions-house, Surrey—(read—Convicted 18th March, 1844, confined three months, and whipped.)—the prisoner is the person.

WRIGHT—
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Three Months.

HEATH—
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Nine Months.

1026.
EDWARD MERRYWEATHER
was indicated for stealing 1 sixpence, the monies of
Flavius Josephus Hudson, his master.

FLAVIUS JOSEPHUS HUDSON . I ama grocer, and live in York-place, Old Kent-road—the prisoner was my shopman for six montha—the first two months he had 3s. a week, and then 3s. 6d.—he had his board—in consequence of suspicion, I opened his box with a key, on Friday, the 28th of March, and on that evening I left in my till, as usual, two sixpences, and 1s. worth of coppers—next morning I came down, about eight o'clock—I

then found in the till 3s. 6d. in silver, and 9 1/2d. in coppers—directly after breakfast I said to the prisoner, "You must have money in your pocket, which does not belong to you; I can bring parties to prove they have laid out 3s. this morning, and you have only 2s. 3 1/2d. to show for it" (that was besides the 2s. I had left in the till the night previous)—I said, "I must see what you have in your pocket"—he said, "You are quite welcome"—he took out of his pocket one shilling, one sixpence, and 2 3/4d., and laid it on the counter—he said, "You see I have no marked money here; when you mark money again, take care to mark it smaller, for I saw the money was marked yesterday"—I examined the money he laid down, and observed the sixpence was marked;—I said, "Here, then, is a sixpence marked smaller, how did you come by that?"—he made no answer—I then said, "I must see in your box"—he said, "You shall, before I go"—I said, "No, I must see at once"—he said, "You shall, if you fetch a policeman"—I fetched one, and we went up stairs together—the prisoner opened his box, and we found in it a tin box, containing 17s. in silver—he turned out the silver, and put the box down again—I took it up, and opened an interior box, and turned out of it eleven sovereigns—I said, "How did you come by all this money? it cannot be yours, from the low wages you have had here, and what you had prior to your coming, being out of place, this money can't belong to you"—he said, "No, part of it belongs to my brother, and part is mine"—I said, "You know very well this is not your money; this belongs to me; you might have a little money belonging to you; if you like to take the silver and copper, you may go away"—being a father, I did not wish to put the law in full force against him—he said, "No," he should not do that, and I gave him in charge—this is the marked sixpence—here is a small scratch on the nose, which my wife made, but not in my presence—I only saw it when I took it out of the till.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. When you made him this liberal offer, he said, "I shall not give it up, I will go to the station? A. Yes—I opened his box the day before with a key from a bunch of keys we have in our possession'—the first key I tried fitted the box—I had never looked into his box before—my wife looked in after I had named the circumstance to her—I looked in on the Friday that we marked the money, and I looked in again the next morning, and 3s. 6d. more had been added from about the middle of Friday—I had paid him his week's wages on Saturday, the 22nd—when I looked into his box on the Friday I saw coppers amounting to nearly 2s., and I saw him with a respectable suit of clothes on—that gave me suspicion, which was on my mind for a considerable time—there was a deficiency of money on the Thursday, when my wife said she had noticed him serve a great many customers—no other persons go into the shop—no person goes behind the counter but my own children—I found only one marked sixpence on the prisoner—there were two marked shillings in the till that morning, and one shilling and a sixpence not marked.

COURT. Q. You only put two sixpences and a shilling's worth of copper into the till? A. Yes, I did, but there had been two marked shillings passed by customers that morning—I found the two marked shillings in the till, and only one marked sixpence—when the prisoner told me, when I marked money again to mark it smaller, I had not said anything to him about marked money.

MR. ROBINSON. Q. It was a tin box of the prisoner's in which this money was kept? A. Yes, the gold was in another box inside the tin box—I indicted him for stealing the eleven sovereigns—I have been told the Grand Jury have thrown out that bill—I had frequently missed money—I do not apprehend it was taken in sovereigns.

MARY ANN HUDSON . I am the prosecutor's wife. I saw the eleven sove
reigns and 13s. 6d. in the prisoner's box on the Friday afternoon, and that evening I marked two shillings and two sixpences—I gave the two shillings to Mr. Fairing ton, and the two sixpences to Mrs. Pritchard, to lay out at our shop—on this sixpence produced here is a scratch at the nose, and a piece cut out at the side, in a line with it—I know the mark, and the date of the sixpence was taken as well—I can speak to this as my own mark—I never marked any other sixpences in my life.

WILLIAM FARRINOTON . I am a baker, and live in Windsor-place, Old Kent-road. My wife showed me two marked shillings—I sent the servant girl with them to the prosecutor's shop for some articles—I took a me
morandum of the date and reign of the two shillings—I received two marked sixpences from Mrs. Pritchard's sister—I put down the date and reign of them—they were marked on the top of the nose and on the edge—I sent the boy out with both the sixpences—this sixpence is one of them—it is of the year 1840—it is one that Mrs. Pritchard's sister gave me, and one I sent by the boy.

Joseph Biggs. I am employed occasionally by Mr. Farrington to go on errands. On that Saturday morning, about twenty minutes to eight o'clock, he gave me two sixpences, to go to Mr. Hudson's shop, to fetch 2oz. of tea and 1 lb. of sugar—they came to 1s.—I paid the two sixpences for them that I had from Mr. Farrington—I did not notice them.

BENJAMIN—(police-constable M 107.) I searched the prisoner's box with Mr. Hudson—I found in it eleven sovereigns, fifteen shillings, four sixpences, and a lot of coppers—I heard Mr. Hudson say to the prisoner, "There is no doubt the sovereigns belong to me; if you will give me the sovereigns, you may take the silver, and go about your business"—the prisoner said part of the money belonged to his brother—this is the box—it has been a lucifer-box, I believe—this is the marked sixpence I had of Mr. Hudson.

MRS. MERRYWEATHER. I am the prisoner's mother. I know he had money in his possession about last June—I saw it—there were six sove
reigns and some silver—he was of a remarkably saving turn—I know of his having a suit of clothes nearly two years—he got them at his first place—they were left by his master for mourning.

CATHARINE EVANS . I live in Waterloo-street, Walworth. I have known the prisoner three years—I saw some money in his box, where he placed his clothes, three or four months before he went to Mr. Hudson's—he had six sovereigns, besides some silver, which I did not see counted he had a black coat, black trowsera, and a blue satin waistcoat.

COURT to MR. HUDSON. Q. What were the clothes the prisoner had? A. He had a blue satin waistcoat for one thing—I think his coat was black, and he had a pair of Wellington boots, which appeared new—I had missed money frequently—I reckoned up the wages I had paid him, and they were about 4l. 7s.—he has a brother in some employ—I missed 8 1/2d. in amount that morning—I knew it was the intention to lay out the whole

of the 2s. at my shop, and I ascertained that the whole of it was laid out—Mr. Farrington has the articles put down that were bought, but the woman who bought them is not here—she was at the office, but not bound over—I attend very closely to the business of my shop, but I was not there when the 2s. were laid out—it is my custom to give the prisoner the key in a morning, and he comes down and opens the shop while I am dressing.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Three Months.

1027.
ROBERT ROBARTS was indicted
for embezzling 11s. 6d., the monies of
Thomas Sorrell, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

1028.
EDWARD ASHTON was indicted
for stealing 1 pair of boots, value 3s. 6d., the goods of
William Green and another, his masters; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 21.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Two Months.

1029.
MARY MORRIS was indicted
for unlawfully uttering counter
feit coin; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

1030.
JOHN JONES and
JOHN WARD were indicted for
unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.
NOT GUILTY .

1031.
JAMES HATCHER was indicted
for stealing 2 coats, value 3l., the goods of
John Mumford; and that he had been before convicted of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1032.
WILLIAM WRIGHT was indicted
for stealing 1 1/2 lb. weight of tripe, value 8d.; 1/2 lb. weight of sausages, 3d.; 1 loaf of bread, 3d.; and 1 handkerchief, 7d.; the goods of
William Browning, from the person of
Mary Ann Browning; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

MARY ANN BROWNING . I am the wife of William Browning, of King William-street. On the evening of the 20th of March I was in Tooley-street, carrying a bundle, containing the tripe, the bread, and other things mentioned—I was pushed down in the street, and my bundle taken from me—I am quite sure I was pushed down, and with violence—I fell down, and my bundle was snatched from me—the prisoner is the man who pushed me down, and who took my bundle—I am sure of that—I saw him, and followed him—I met with the officer—this is my handkerchief—I can swear to it—it was round the bundle, and a loaf was found, which resembled the loaf I lost.

HENRY HUNT (police-constable M 82.) Between six and seven o'clock that evening I was on duty in Tooley-street—I received information from Mrs. Browning—I went and met the prisoner at the bottom of Ball-court, with a loaf in one hand, and a handkerchief in the other—I said, "What is this?"—he said, "Some bread, and this is my handkerchief"—I did not
take him then, but went and spoke to the prosecutrix—I then went back to the prisoner—he still had the loaf in his hand—he threw it down—this handkerchief I found in his pocket.
Prisoner. Q. Did I not say I picked them up? A. No.

Prisoner. I picked them up in the court; the officer came, and I told him what I had got; he came back in five minutes, and took me; I made no resistance; the prosecutrix said she thought I was the person.

MARY ANN BROWNING
re-examined. I am quite certain he is the person—I never thought anything about it.
THOMAS WEST (police-constable M 249.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got at the Surrey Session—(read—Convicted on the 5th of May, 1844, and confined six months.)

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Ten Years.

1032.
EDWARD OWEN was indicted
for embezzling 2l. 15s., of
John Johnson Kirby, his master, to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 45.—
Confined Nine Months.

1033.
HANNAH LEARY was indicted
for stealing 3 lbs. weight of beef, value 1s. 3d., the property of
Joseph Smith; and that she had been before convicted of felony.

JOSEPH SMITH . I am a butcher, and live in the Lower Marsh, Lambeth. On the 15th of March, about half-past ten o'clock at night, I was outside my door, and saw the prisoner come and take a piece of salt beef out of the salt beef tray—she walked off with it—I followed, and asked her to give it me—she would not, but dropped it—it was mine.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not take another woman as well as me? A. Yes, I thought she was connected with her, but the prisoner took the beef.
Prisoner's Defence. I am quite innocent.

VALENTINE TITE (police-constable L 45.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's conviction, which I got from the Sessions House, New
ington—(read—Convicted on the 2nd of December, 1844, andconfined three months)—she is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Six Months.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY THE 12TH OF MAY.
